story: NewsWoman ordered to cough up demons during twisted gay conversion therapy sessionEXCLUSIVE: A Sunday People probe lts the lid on the hateful practice of conversion therapy, which one campaigner says is ¬≠comparable to torture because it leads to self-loathing and for some, suicidal thoughtsmirrorShareCommentsByAmy SharpeSunday Mirror reporter:,  MAY NewsReporter Daniel Harding poses as Joe Willis on a video call to find out more about conversion therapy " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeCampaigners demand gay ‚Äúconversion therapy‚Äù is banned immediately as a Sunday People probe lts the lid on the hateful practice. In the Queen‚Äôs Speech the Government said it would outlaw the ‚Äútreatment‚Äù, which tries to change someone‚Äôs sexual orientation or gender identity. But experts are appalled by the likely delay in a ban and the possible loopholes a new law may leave for the practice to continue.A letter from Boris Johnson to the Evangelical Alliance told church ¬≠leaders ‚Äúnon-coercive‚Äù support for gay ¬≠people ‚Äì including praying over their sexuality ‚Äì will escape a ban.Crispin Blunt, of Parliament‚Äôs group on global LGBT rights, accused the PM of ‚Äúbreaching‚Äù the trust of LGBT people. One campaigner said LGBT conversion therapy is ¬≠comparable to torture because it leads to self-loathing and many people subjected to it consider killing themselves. The practice has also been called ineffective, unethical, and potentially ¬≠harmful by professional bodies. We launched our investigation after three advisers quit the Government‚Äôs LGBT ¬≠advisory  in March. They were frustrated by a lack of action to ban the practice. There were also claims ministers were ¬≠‚Äúignorant‚Äù about gay rights ¬≠issues and had created a ‚Äúhostile environment‚Äù for LGBT people.Have you or someone you know gone been subjected to conversion therapy  If so email webnews@reachplc Our reporter Daniel Harding, who is gay, posed as confused Joe Willis, seeking guidance after being secretly attracted to men all his le. He had a video call with Matthew Grech, co-director of Christian fundamentalist charity Core Issues Trust, which claims to have helped people ‚Äúovercome same-sex attraction‚Äù and, in some cases, ‚Äúleave homosexuality behind‚Äù. Ahead of the Zoom session, Grech told Joe men keen to reduce same-sex attraction ‚Äúnormally have to work on things like being more assertive, being less shy... and receiving male friendships in a healthy way‚Äù.During the video call Grech, a contestant in ‚Äôs X Factor Malta, said: ‚ÄúI do have friends around me who say, ‚ÄòMatthew, I once ¬≠identied as exclusively gay and now I am married and I have children and I completely overcame same-sex attraction‚Äô.‚ÄùGrech quizzed Joe about his childhood, relationships with his dad and male friends and askedthere was ‚Äúa history of sexual abuse‚Äù. He said: ‚ÄúI come from an understanding that is not based on ideology but on science ‚Äì that nobody is born with same-sex relations. The ¬≠majority of the influence lies in environmental factors. ‚ÄúOur minds form patterns which can be changed to ¬≠create new ways of thinking... so that we can take authority over our thoughts and train ¬≠ourselves in a new way. ‚ÄúEveryone who embarks on this journey will say to you at least that their same-sex attraction has decreased.‚Äù  When Joe asked why he is attracted to men, Grech replied: ‚ÄúI honestly think that you didn‚Äôt really fit what you ¬≠perceived to be the stereotype in boys your age... I believe a misunderstanding took place that led to confusion. ‚ÄúWhat that confusion does is it brings manipulation ‚Äì it manipulates your desires. ‚ÄúAnd then that ¬≠manipulation causes frustration, causes ¬≠irritation and it violates your relationship with other men.‚Äù He said Joe would need to ‚Äúgo back to the root‚Äù of his feelings and deal with them but warned it is harder later in le once thoughts have ‚Äútaken root‚Äù. Asked how he could stop fancying men, Grech told Joe ‚Äúmaster your body‚Äù and said: ‚ÄúWe need to manage our ¬≠hunger and thirst for connection in an appropriate way... and then work on seeing ¬≠ourselves as equal to other men.‚Äù Grech claimed some people might say Joe was ‚Äúborn that way, blah blah blah,‚Äù but said: ‚ÄúWe just don‚Äôt listen to that stuff because they‚Äôre misguided‚Äù. When Joe said he wanted marriage and children, Grech told him homosexuality ‚Äúrobs [gay people] of family as God intended family to be‚Äù and said there are ‚Äúa lot of repercussions‚Äù. When Joe askedGrech thought he was gay, he replied: ‚ÄúNo‚Ä¶ what you feel is not who you are‚Ä¶ If tomorrow I feel like I‚Äôm a woman, does that make me a woman ‚Äù He claimed even the label ‚Äúgay‚Äù is damaging as it ‚Äúteaches people to make their feelings their identity‚Äù. Core Issues Trust was still advertising this week. It‚Äôs website describes CIT as a ‚Äúnon-profit Christian ministry supporting men and women with homosexual issues who voluntarily seek change in sexual preference and expression‚Äù and states: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd love to hear from you and support your journey!‚Äù In , then Prime Minister Theresa May promised to end conversion therapy but before legislation is brought in there will be a consultation period to consider religious freedoms and how to protect accredited professionals.Campaigners fear further delays will put more LGBT people at risk. Nancy Kelley, head of LGBT charity Stonewall, said: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need a ¬≠consultation to know all practices that seek to convert, suppress, cure or change us are dangerous, abusive and must be banned. Lesbian, gay, bi, trans, intersex and ace communities have been waiting ¬≠almost three years for the UK Government to follow through on their promise to ban all conversion ¬≠practices, and any delay leaves us at further risk of abuse.‚Äù Jayne Ozanne, a founding ¬≠member of the Archbishops‚Äô Council charity, is gay and had a decade of conversion therapy that led to a mental ¬≠breakdown. She said: ‚ÄúThose who continue to practise conversion therapy inflict enormous harm by feeding off an ¬≠inidual‚Äôs internalised homophobia and shame. They undermine core family ¬≠relationships by blaming them for a person‚Äôs ‚Äúsame-sex attraction‚Äù, ¬≠stubbornly refusing to accept that our sexuality is something to be celebrated and true happiness can only be found when we embrace the truth about who we are. The damage to a person‚Äôs sense of self and dignity is immense. ‚ÄúIt is why it has been called torture, leading to a letime of self-¬≠loathing, which sadly leads many to contemplate suicide.‚Äù She is ‚Äúrelieved‚Äù the Government plans to ban it but said: ‚ÄúI am deeply concerned that they may leave a legal loophole open for these harmful religious practices to continue. ‚ÄúThe Government‚Äôs failure to understand how damaging these ¬≠religious practices are, and how young LGBT people of faith are groomed to agree to go through them, was one of the primary reasons I felt I had to resign from the Government‚Äôs LGBT advisory .‚Äù She is director of the Ozanne Foundation which, in a  survey, found that one in ten of , LGBT respondents had tried to change sexual orientation. Of these, over half had suffered mental health issues and a third attempted suicide. Grech reached the judges‚Äô houses stage of Malta‚Äôs X Factor, which was ¬≠criticised for airing a ¬≠pre-audition ¬≠interview in which he claimed people of the same sex can be friends, but ‚Äúeverything  is a sin‚Äù. After the Zoom session, Daniel, , said: ‚ÄúIt felt like I was venturing into a cult. It‚Äôs atrocious and should be stopped immediately. ‚ÄúI felt sad for Matthew, the ¬≠information he shared and believed and for people who approach thinking they will be helped when in fact it will hinder them. I also felt anger at being told my feelings are mistaken.‚Äù More than  senior figures from  nations, representing  religions, have signed a ¬≠declaration calling for a global ban on conversion practices. The Royal College of Psychiatrists backs a full legislative ban. A spokesman said the practice has no scientic basis and was shown to be harmful. CIT founder Mike Davidson said it supports those ‚Äúfailed‚Äù by mental health services, claiming they ‚Äúabandoned iniduals in conflict over their sexuality, agreeing to offer gay-affirming therapies only. ‚ÄúBanning therapeutic choice ‚Äì the real purpose of ‚Äòconversion therapy‚Äô bans ‚Äì is a violation of the basic human rights of belief and association.‚Äù He also said a ban would restrict freedom of speech and reduce or impede ¬≠religious freedoms.aposI was made to feel like an abominationapos Gay Jayne Ozanne spent thousands of pounds and ten years on conversion therapy in her s after being made to feel ‚Äúdeeply ashamed‚Äù about her sexuality. Now , she said: ‚ÄúYou tell a religious leader you‚Äôre suffering from ‚Äòsame sex attraction‚Äô they will come along and pray. Praying sounds benign. It is anything but.‚Äú The ex-member of the Government‚Äôs LGBT advisory  said: ‚ÄúPeople you trust will go through every aspect of your le to find any reason to explain why you‚Äôre not gay. You start praying more desperately and when you say it‚Äôs not working you are told you don‚Äôt have enough faith or you‚Äôre not praying enough. ‚ÄúI was told I would have to be single and celibate for le. I was made to feel deeply ashamed, like an abomination. ‚ÄúThis led me to try and find more extreme healing in the UK and overseas ‚Äì exorcisms or visiting deliverance ministries - those who feel they have a specic gt in this area. I found myself being sick, I‚Äôd be encouraged to cough up demons and look in the mirror and my eyes would pop. ‚ÄúI remember one guy hitting me because they believed the devil was inside of me. You are never charged a fee ‚Äì it is suggested you give what God is telling you to give. I gave thousands as I thought it was the right thing to do.‚Äù Years of therapy took her to a ‚Äúvery dark place‚Äù, and in her late s Jayne was hospitalised after suffering a breakdown. In  she came out to family and fell in love with a woman. ‚ÄúIt transformed me,‚Äù she said. Now, she campaigns to ensure inclusion of all LGBT people of faith, particularly in churches, through the Ozanne Foundation and is part of the Ban Conversion Therapy coalition. aposPeople would yell at me to release my demonsapos One woman told how she hid her sexuality for  years and attempted suicide after undergoing conversion therapy, aged , in Berkshire. Sam, , not her real name, became a Christian in her late teens, and recalls being told that homosexuality is a sin when she said she was gay. She said: ‚ÄúNobody called it conversion therapy ‚Äì I was told someone would pray with me. I was told I‚Äôm not gay as God would never make people that way. Instead I was probably demon possessed and had childhood trauma that made me think I was gay and I needed to be set free. There was shouting, yelling at demons to release me and I was made to confess my sins, repent and apologise so God could forgive me.‚Äù Sam went into denial about her sexuality and even married a man, but her mental health suffered and in  she made an attempt on her le. She feels ‚Äúhuge relief after coming out last year‚Äù. ‚ÄúMy old church still offers this sort of thing and it makes me angry. Young people processing their sexuality need to be protected. It‚Äôs not gay rights verses Christian rights ‚Äì it‚Äôs a human rights issue.‚ÄùMPs call for fast action Equalities Minister Liz Truss said that the Government has ‚Äúalways been committed‚Äù to ending conversion therapy. Ms Truss said: ‚ÄúWe want to make sure that people in this country are protected, and these proposals mean nobody will be subjected to coercive and abhorrent conversion therapy. ‚ÄúAlongside this legislation, we will make new funding available to ensure that victims have better access to the support they need.‚Äù But Shadow Equalities Secretary Marsha de Cordova dismissed this as ‚Äúyet another example of words but no action‚Äù. She accused the Government of failing to provide ‚Äúspecic legislation‚Äù. She added: ‚ÄúInstead of yet another consultation we need to see concrete action to ban these despicable practices. ‚ÄúDelay only causes further harm to LGBT+ people.‚Äù Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran said: ‚ÄúAlmost three years since ministers promised to ban conversion therapy, the Government is still dragging its feet, insisting we need another consultation before legislation in this week‚Äôs Queen‚Äôs Speech. ‚ÄúWhat LGBT+ people need is change now.‚Äù Stonewall ‚Äì part of the Ban Conversion Therapy coalition ‚Äì want a full Bill published now, with a clear timeline for its implementation.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnBoris JohnsonHuman rightsGayPoliticsSexualitySunday People

Stephanie Phillips and William Hosier have decided to get married having been together since .The -year-old, whose father is the daughter of Princess Anneaposs first husband Captain Mark Phillips, announced the news on Instagram.Worcester-based event rider Stephanie shared the big news the day before Zaraaposs th birthday. She posted a series of photos of herself with her fianc√©, an agriculture graduate who is believed to have popped the question on May . Stephanie showed off a large sapphire and diamond engagement ring in the snaps. One well-wisher wrote beneath the posts: Congratulations Steph! Wonderful, happy news.  Another commented: Huge congratulations. Today royal fans took to social media to wish Zara a happy birthday, having announced in March she is expecting a baby. Royals Peter and Zara have a rarely talked about their younger sister, who generally keeps herself away from the limelight. It is well known that Princess Anne keeps her family close at her  acre country estate in Gloucestershire. What is less widely publicised is that her children Peter Philips and Zara Tindall have another sibling.  Stephanie Phillips is not the child of Princess Anne but of her former husband Captain Phillips and his second we Hawaiian equestrian Sandy Pflueger. The -year-old horse enthusiast grew up not far from Peter and Zara on a nearby farm on the Gatcombe Park estate following the split of her parents in . While there is an age gap sitting between Zara, , and Peter, , and their younger sibling, the bond between them seems to be tight. Stephanie was a flower girl at both their weddings and is well involved in the family.  One cute snap shared on social media shows the horse rider giving Mike Tindal a piggyback. Stephanie went to Dean Close School in Cheltenham, which caters for boarders and day students, before going on to the University of Worcester. Like her mother, who was part of the US dressage team in the  Olympics and worked across the world, and her father who spent years in America training the US team, Stephanie seems to enjoy travelling. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTwo travel pals have revealed how they were ambushed on a beach in Thailand ‚Äì at the same spot where Brits David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were murdered six years ago. Sam Venning and Carla Bartel said two men in V for Vendetta masks attacked them on Koh Tao island a year before David, , and Hannah, , died. They say they offered information to authorities probing David and Hannah‚Äôs deaths ‚Äì but were never interviewed. They have now come forward to offer their help to lawyers for the two migrant workers found guilty of the killing. They are trying to prove conviction is unsafe.  Brit tech firm boss Sam ‚Äì  at the time ‚Äì says he was smashed on the head with a rock as he chatted with -year-old Carla on Sairee beach. He said of seeing TV footage after the murder in September : ‚ÄúIt was horric, I was right there where their bodies were. ‚ÄúIt was where I literally face-planted the sand.‚Äù  Koh Tao has since become known as Death Island after gaining a sinister reputation for deaths and disappearances.And justice campaigners have raised doubts over the convictions of the two Burmese men ‚Äì prompting fears the real killers may still be at large there. Sam, an e-commerce boss who now lives in San Francisco, says he emailed the Thai embassy in London after the killings offering to give a statement but never heard back. And Carla contacted the UK Foreign Commonwealth Office in her native Canada ‚Äì and received an email from a Bangkok-based officer at the UK National Crime Agency telling her the information would be shared with Thai police. She heard nothing more.  Carla said of the island paradise: ‚ÄúMany tourists go there every year. I feel people need to know what goes on.‚Äù At least nine European tourists have died or gone missing on the island in the last decade, including six Brits. In  a British teen reported being drugged, tied up and raped on the same beach. In , Burmese workers Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were sentenced to death for David and Hannah‚Äôs murders. But the case was mired in allegations of a cover-up and mishandled forensics. The men claimed they were tortured by the Royal Thai Police into confessing.  Human Rights Watch called the guilty verdicts ‚Äúprofoundly disturbing‚Äù. In  the NCA admitted breaking UK law by sharing information with Thai authorities ‚Äì as Britain opposes capital punishment. Last year the death senten¬≠¬≠ces were overturned by Thai¬≠¬≠land‚Äôs king Maha Vajiralongkorn, but the men remain in jail. Sam and Carla‚Äôs ordeal emerged after both gave video interviews to Australian lawyer Ian Yarwood, who runs an online group about safety on Koh Tao. Andy Hall, a migrant workers‚Äô rights activist and international affairs advisor to Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo‚Äôs legal team, told us: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good this evidence has been brought forward, we can consider whether we can use it as a means to reopen the case.‚Äù The National Crime Agency said: ‚ÄúThe NCA‚Äôs assistance to the Thai authorities in  was provided in good faith in the context of a fast moving investigation into the murders of two British citizens. ‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt comment on the assistance provided but can confirm all relevant information relating to that investigation was shared with Thai authorities.‚Äù The Thai embassy did not respond to requests for comment.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorMore OnHuman Rights WatchWai PhyoAndy HallMurderHuman rightsCrime

story: BORDERS football will remain suspended until at least February .On January , SFA chiefs said lower league matches across Scotland would be halted for three weeks.But today , bosses have confirmed the shutdown of isions beneath the Championship has been extended.The suspension affects Gala Fairydean Rovers and Vale of Leithen who play in the Lowland League as well as Peebles Rovers, Coldstream, Hawick Royal Albert United and Eyemouth, who compete in East of Scotland conferences.:Borders Railway: Train times to change next month, ScotRail announcesRod Petrie, the Scottish FA president, said: ldquoThe conversations we have had with representatives from the clubs and leagues affected by the temporary suspension have been hugely beneficial."We have been able to further communicate the rationale behind the decision in the midst of an ongoing pandemic whilst also hearing at first hand the most important issues facing clubs and leagues at each level of the game."We have also been greatly encouraged by the sense of togetherness shown by the clubs and the robustness with which protocols and measures have been implemented in the interests of player and staff safety within football.:Coronavirus: NHS Borders gives apology as routine operations pushed back further"A number of initiatives have been suggested which may help to make the eventualto playing efficient without compromising safety."The decision to extend the suspension is necessary given the Scottish Governmentrsquos own extension of existing lockdown measures."Football will play its part to support the collective effort to reduce the spread of the new iants of the COVID- virus."We are grateful for the input of all groups involved in our online discussions this week and we will continue to liaise ahead of our next public update on February ."

title: coronavirus-borders-football-suspension-extended-sfa
story: THE Scottish Football Association has announced that the current suspension of football beneath the Championship will be extended further.The temporary suspension ndash announced by the SFA on January  ndash was extended for the first time until February .However, an announcement on Tuesdayconfirmed that the suspension would be extended again, with nodate currently set.The suspension affects Gala Fairydean Rovers and Vale of Leithen, who compete in the Lowland League.Peebles Rovers, Coldstream, Hawick Royal Albert United and Eyemouth are the other Borders clubs impacted by the decision.:Woman charged after large quantity of drugs found in vehicle on Borders roadA spokesperson for the SFA said: ldquoIn recent weeks, the Scottish FA has engaged extensively with clubs and leagues affected by the suspension of professional football across the menrsquos and womenrsquos game to discuss tailoredto playing plans for implementation when it is considered safe and appropriate to resume.ldquoWe have also remained in regular dialogue with Scottish Government to ensure their input into and ultimately approval of those proposed plans.ldquoRegrettably, the government has today confirmed that ndash in cognisance of the current restrictions in place across the country ndash they cannot currently commit todates for those affected leagues in the coming weeks.ldquoWe will continue to speak with all parties in the meantime and will provide a further update by  March.ldquoThis date should not be seen as a proposed restart date, however it should help provide some clarity to affected clubs to aid their planning over the short term.ldquoWhilst this is disappointing news, Scottish football will continue to play its part in assisting the Scottish Governmentrsquos efforts to reduce the prevalence of COVID- across the country.

title: six-nations-rugby-darcy-graham-play-scotland-vs-wales
story: DARCY GRAHAM is set to start against Wales on Saturday as Scotland look to make it two wins from two in this yearrsquos Six Nations campaign.Gregor Townsend saw his side record an historic victory at Twickenham last weekend, with Scotland running out - winners to take home the Calcutta Cup.However, the victory has taken a toll on Townsendrsquos side, who will be without three starters from last weekend due to injury when they face Wales at BT Murrayfield on Saturday .Jamie Ritchie , Sean Maitlandand the impressive Cameron Redpathwill all be forced to watch the game from the sidelines.:Ex-Borders rugby player named farmer of the year in UK awards ceremonyThe injuries have opened the door for Borderer Darcy Graham to go from the start. He played when the two nations met in October.The Edinburgh winger, from Hawick, joins fellow Borderers Rory Sutherland and captain Stuart Hogg ndash both also from Hawick ndash in the starting XV.Meanwhile, two uncapped Borderers have been called up to the Scotland squad.Ex-Earlston High School student George Taylor and Charlie Shiel, born in Melrose, have been added to the squad by Townsend.Shiel, , is the son of former Scotland international Graham Shiel, who turned out for Melrose in the late eighties.Scotland team to play Wales: Stuart Hogg , Darcy Graham , Chris Harris , James Lang , Duhan van der Merwe , Finn Russell , Ali Price , Rory Sutherland , George Turner , Zander Fagerson , Scott Cummings , Jonny Gray , Blade Thomson , Hamish Watson , Matt Fagerson Substitutes: David Cherry , Oli Kebble , WP Nel , Richie Gray , Gary Graham , Scott Steele , Jaco van der Walt , Huw Jones

title: lowland-league-gala-fairydean-rovers-finish-6th
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers could be about to record their highest-ever finish in the Lowland League with a sixth-placed position.The league has been unable to get the go-ahead from the Scottish Football Association to resume playing after the season was put on hold in January due to increasing coronaviruscases nationwide.Declaring the season null and void would mean that the Lowland Leagues top team would not be able to go forward to the play-offs to try and earn a place in Division Two.Board members are now set to discuss a proposal to call a halt to the league and use a formula ofaverage points per game to calculate the final league positions for the  clubs.As things stand, Kelty Hearts would be champions and would compete in the play-offs with Brora Rangers, with the winners then playing the bottom team in Division Two.Using the average points formula, Gala would leapfrog Stirling University into sixth position which would be their highest-ever finish since the introduction of the Lowland League in .East Kilbride would be runners-up,with Bonnyrigg third, followed by BSC Glasgow, East Stirlingshire and then Gala Fairydean Rovers.The relegation issue - with Vale of Leithen currently pointless at the bottom - has still to be resolved and is due to be discussed at the board meeting.Gala chairman Ryan Cass said:"We will have to wait for the outcome of the meeting to see what is happening."Butthe league is settled by an average of points-per-game then finishing sixth - with our playing budget compared with other big-spendingclubs in the league - is a great achievement."However I am personally disappointedthe league does not resume because I feel we could have finished even higher."The league stopping could not have happened at a worse time for us because the team was playing well having recorded a deserved win at Boness and narrowly losing to Annan Athletic in the Scottish Cup in a game we could easily have won."Manager Neil Hastings and his coaches have done a tremendous job and built a team playing a brand of football that the town can beproud of."If the league is called off now then we would just have to accept it and then start preparing for next season when hopefully restrictions are lted and we can get spectators back at our games."The majority of the squad have re-signed for next season and there will be some new faces coming into the squad as we want to continue improving and challenging at the top of the table."

title: scotland-staycation-ideas-guide-scottish-hebrides-lockdown-rules-ease
story: With the country emerging from lockdown many Scots are turning their attention to summer staycations.The newly relaxed rules ndash introduced on April  - allow travel across the country for socialising, recreation, or exercise.Yet it seems unlikely that Scots will be able to travel abroad any time soon, as strict self-isolation rules remain in place.But with a wealth of history, culture, and wildle to explore on your doorstep, staycations are the perfect way to spend this summer.Island hopping allows travellers to see some of the most untouched and scenic parts of the country.So, herersquos a small sample of what the Scottish Hebrides have to offer when the rules permit overnight stays.Isle of BarraBarra is a small, tranquil island located in the most southern point of the Outer Hebrides.Itrsquos only eight miles long and four miles wide, with a population of about .Barrarsquos rich in beautul white sand beaches, wild grasslands, lochs, and panoramic views.It was recently ranked first as the most beautul island in Britain and has a distinct culture and fascinating history.The Heaval, Barrarsquos highest hill, stands at ft offering spectacular views of the island.Visitors can take a five-minute boat trip out to the Kisimul Castle, built around , which sits on a rocky island.Alternatively, you can walk on one of the islandrsquos five beaches, fish in one of the seven lochs, or explore some of the  cycle routes on offer.You can travel to Barra via ferry from Oban or Eriskay.Alternatively, you can travel by air from Glasgow or Benbecula.Flying to the island is very popular as the runway isnrsquot made out of tarmac but isnrsquot sand and sea.Barra Airport is unique as the only commercial airport in the world where scheduled flights use the beach as a runway.Plane arriving on the beach at Barra AirportAccommodation ranges from camping, to hostels, to hotels.Isle of EiggEigg is one of the most beautul community owned islands in the Inner Hebrides, situated about ten miles off the Scottish West coast.Itrsquos one of the smallest Hebridean Islandrsquos on the west coast at only five miles long and three miles wide.But what it lacks in size, it makes up in beauty and character.Eigg has a captivating history, untouched wildle, and a vibrant community.Visitors can canoe in the clear blue seas, watch eagles over stunning white beaches, cycle theof the island, explore the caves, or climb Britainrsquos largest pitchstone ridge.You can travel to Eigg on ferry from Mallaig or Arisaig, or on a sailing yacht with Selkie Explorers.Sunset from the ferryAccommodation on offer includes camping, glamping, yurts, cabins, and bothies.Isle of IslayIslay is known as The Queen of the Hebrides and is the southernmost island in the Inner Hebrides, just north of Northern Ireland.Itrsquos the fth-largest island in the British Isles at  miles long and  miles wide, with just over , residents.Islay is known for its peaty, smoky whiskies and is home to nine working distilleries ndash which is celebrated in the Islay Festival.The festival will run from May  to June , transforming the island with traditional music, whisky tasting, ceilidhrsquos, Gaelic lessons, and golf.The islandrsquos dramatic landscapes are widely celebrated through art.Fair Isle You can reach Islay via plane from Glasgow or Oban.Alternatively, you can take the ferry from Kennacraig near the top of the Kintyre peninsula.Theresan array of hotels on offer for travellers to book in to.

title: 20-best-gardens-scotland-visit-post-lockdown-weekend
story: As National Gardening Week came to a close, wersquore gearing up to get green-fingered again.And where better to seek inspiration than in Scotlandrsquos gorgeous outdoor spaces  From castles with historic walled gardens to botanic idylls with their own microclimate and even contemporary sculpture parks, you might be surprised by the ersity found across the country.Whether you want to admire the rhododendrons in bloom at this time of year or you really miss the sight of palm trees, yoursquoll find no shortage of options to sate your inner botanist.Drummond Castle Gardens, Crieffpound entry If a garden can masquerade in Outlander as one belonging to the Palace of Versailles, you know itrsquos something special.Drummond Castle was likely selected as a shoot location in part because its formal Italianate garden was designed by Lewis Kennedy, who had worked for the Empress Joseacutephine at Malmaison in France.The striking parterres are distinctly Scottish, however, denoting the Drummond family coat of arms with traversing paths that centre on a stone obelisk sundial.Statues, urns and fountains add to its grand, palatial feel, neatly separated by ancient yew hedges. The castle isnrsquot open to the public, but yoursquoll be too bewitched by its grounds to care.drummondcastlegardensCambo Gardens, Kingsbarnspound. entry The .-acre Victorian walled garden at Cambo Estate in Fe flowers with lilacs, rambling roses, elegant willows and naturalistic plantings that lend it a wild and romantic feel despite being carefully cultivated.Right now it is carpeted with tulips, and a visit later in summer will reward you with peonies. Cambo Burn runs through the garden ndash you can stop to admire it from the wrought-iron bridge ndash and therersquos even a burbling waterfall.Within the wider estate lies a winter garden and North American style prairie with tall grasses.Recent investment means the newly reopened Cambo Garden shop is now double the size with a wide iety of cut flowers, plants and gts for sale.cambogardens.org.ukThe Secret Herb Garden, EdinburghFree entryHusband and we Hamish and Libs Martin were inspired by the novel The Secret Garden to create a sprawling green space on the outskirts of Edinburgh where people could absorb the beauty of nature.And so The Secret Herb Garden was born.The garden incorporates a herb nursery with more than  ieties the Secret Garden Distilleryand the Root to Market shop which sells garden-grown produce and items from local makers.Seasonal food is served in Fhior Garden Cafeacute, located in a plant-filled glasshouse. Distillery and gin garden tours will recommence on nd May.secretherbgardenCulzean Castle, Maybolepound entry With its dramatic clf-top location, Culzean Castle cuts an impressive figure.Itrsquos easy to be swept up in the majesty of the historic building, but donrsquot skip the opportunity to explore its magnicent grounds.Therersquos an th-century walled garden where fruit and vegetables grow, a Victorian orangery brimming with fragrant citrus trees, and  hectaresof mixed woodland with a coner plantation and swan pond.You may struggle to tear wee ones away from the Adventure Cove and Wild Woodland play parks ndash there are treehouses and zip slides ndash but when they get hungry therersquos the Home Farm Kitchen, currently takeaway-only.nts.org.uk visit places culzeanBenmore Botanic Garden, Dunoonpound. entry Those missing foreign travel can get a taste of it via the plants and trees of Benmore, a satellite outpost of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh.The garden, which benefits from a humid climate thanks to the Gulf Stream, is ided into geographical regions allowing visitors to get up close with monkey puzzle trees in the Chilean Rainforest, Huon pines in the Tasmanian Ridge and Japanese cedars in the Japanese Valley.Benmore is perhaps best known for its rhododendrons ndash there are more than , of them, and this is the best time of year to see them in full, colourful bloom.Therersquos also a Victorian fernery nestled in the hillside and home to many exotic species of feathery foliage.rbge.org.uk visit benmore-botanic-garden Fingask Castle, RaitHonesty box donationYoursquod be forgiven for thinking yoursquod happened upon a Mad Hatterrsquos tea party when visiting Fingask.Surrealist topiary in irregular shapes and bold swirls cascade down the castle lawn, intermingled with stone globes, marble balls and a statue of Alice in Wonderland herself.The castle is private and can be hired for weddings and events, but visitors are welcome to wander the grounds in exchange for a donation to the honesty box in the corner of the car park.From there, follow the sign to St Peterrsquos Well. Positioned in a jungle-like area of the garden, this historic point of interest was once a th-century stop-off point for medieval pilgrims.fingaskcastleGordon Castle Estate, Moraypound entry At more than  years old and spanning eight acres, the walled garden at Gordon Castle is one of Britainrsquos oldest and largest kitchen gardens.Its aesthetic is modern though owners Angus and Zara Gordon Lennox commissioned designer Anne Maynard to reimagine the space with her trademark bold, linear architecture.Six ornamental herbaceous borders frame the garden and inside therersquos a maze, a perfume garden, medicinal herbs, fruit trees, vegetable beds and a dipping pond surrounded by lavender.The gardenrsquos bounty is plated up in the cafeacute and utilised in many of the products for sale in the castle shop, from Gordon Castle gin, cider and ale to skincare, essential oils and candles.gordoncastlescotlandHonesty box donationWhile it would be a bit of a stretch to describe this public oasis in the heart of Glasgowrsquos Southside as a lsquosecretrsquo, there is still an element of surprise when entering the Hidden Gardens. Tucked away behind the post-industrial Tramway arts venue, the gardens offer tranquil escapism from the hustle and bustle of the city. Picnic under the Ginkgo tree, gather culinary inspiration from the herb and mint borders or read in idyllic solitude in the Xylotheque, a library of wooden books detailing dferent kinds of trees native to Scotland. Artwork is peppered throughout, including the newly launched Fly Away Home exhibition, on until the end of May.thehiddengardens.org.uk pound entry This award-winning sculpture garden on the -acreBonnington House estate near Wilkieston blends a lush landscape with contemporary, often whimsical, installations and exhibitions. Curated and run by Robert and Nicky Wilson, itrsquos like an open-air art gallery with the Pentlands as its backdrop. Next weekend will see the unveiling of an installation by Scottish artist Rachel Maclean, taking the form of an abandoned high-street shop amid the woodland. Other permanent works include Joana Vasconcelosrsquo Gateway, a pool garden crafted from more than , hand-painted Portuguese tiles, and Anthony Gormleyrsquos Firmament, a steel sculpture crouched in a field.jupiterartland.orgAchamore Gardens, GighaDonations acceptedThe warm microclimate of the Hebridean isle of Gigha allows sub-tropical species from Australia, New Zealand and Madeira to flourish in Achamore Gardens, created by Colonel James Horlick, a keen botanist, in the s. Its  acresare overseen by an all-female team currently tasked with revitalising the once world-famous garden, but even in its present condition therersquos plenty to admire. Jolly rhododendrons, delicate magnolia trees and fiery pink azaleas are all enlivening the grounds right now and an adventure through the bamboo maze will have you feeling like an intrepid explorer. Keep an ear out for the New Zealand Christmas Tree in the walled garden ndash its nectar brings all the bees to the yard.Backhouse Rossie Estate, Fepound. entry The garden at Backhouse Rossie Estate is themed around art and science, reflecting the ownersrsquo backgrounds ndash one an artist, the other an engineer ndash and the fact their co-joined initials, CG and AT, are the same as the base pairs of DNA molecules. Two cobble-edged pathways shaped like a double helix run from either side to meet at a centrophere-shaped sculpture in the middle. Not science minded  Donrsquot worry: the garden is a joy from a purely aesthetic vantage, with a long archway festooned with white rambling roses, an orchard planted with apple and plum trees and a celestial-inspired grass labyrinth.backhouserossiePriorwood Garden, Melrosepound entry You may have noticed dried floral arrangements have enjoyed a surge in popularity over the past year ndash sales have blossomed by % over the course of the pandemic. If itrsquos a trend you enjoy then perhaps yoursquoll be interested in visiting Priorwood Garden, which is set in Melrose Abbey and contains Scotlandrsquos only dedicated dried flower garden. Apple lovers will find more than  ieties growing in the old orchard, an ideal place to plonk for a picnic. Once yoursquove had your fill yoursquore in close proximity to both the abbey and Harmony Garden, a serene spot with scented borders,you fancy extending your visit.nts.org.uk visit places harmony-gardenJohnston Gardens, AberdeenFreeAberdeen regularly receives accolades for its public parks and gardens, which bring welcome splashes of green to the Granite City. Among the prettiest and most award-winning are Johnston Gardens, a short drive from the heart of the city. At just . acresthe space is easy to navigate and instils a sense of peace in all who stroll through it. Ducks glide on the iris-laced ponds and there are enough burns, waterfalls and rockeries to lull you into a  sense of countryside le. Make a stop on the rustic blue bridge for Instagram points.aberdeencity.gov.ukInverewe, Wester Rosspound in the honesty boxIf itrsquos been a long time since you last set eyes on a palm tree, a trip to Wester Ross will reacquaint you with your best fronds. Warmed by the Gulf Stream, the lush and tropical gardens of Inverewe jostle with an array of plants from across the globe. Giant Calornian redwoods, Himalayan blue poppies and Tasmanian eucalyptus all thrive here and a network of walks throughout the garden ensure a bioerse feast for the senses. Wildle-spotting opportunities abound, too: red squirrels, red deer, otters, seals and golden eagles are often seen throughout the wider estate.nts.org.uk visit places invereweCrathes Castle and Gardens, Banchorypound. entry The almost four-acrewalled garden at Crathes Castle is one of Scotlandrsquos finest. Sitting directly below the castle, it was largely designed in the early th century by Sir James Burnett and his we Sybil, who were heavily influenced by the soothing palettes and textures of the Arts and Crafts movement. The iety of plants and flowers on display is dizzying there are eight garden rooms, each with its own distinct look and feel. A fountain, Portuguese laurels and sculpted topiary dating to the s all add character, and therersquos a greenhouse containing a collection of Malmaison carnations .nts.org.uk visit places crathes-castleArdkinglas, Argyllpound entry For a family day out, look no further than Ardkinglas. Kids will love hitting the Gruffalo trail, which weaves a path through the woods dotted with familiar characters and boards displaying pages from the book. At the end, near a lochan, is a sculpture of the Gruffalo. For grown-up bookworms, therersquos a scriptorium of tree-related poetry and prose from the likes of Voltaire and Spike Milligan in a timber gazebo in the woodland garden. Care more about seeing trees than reading about them  Yoursquore in the right place: among the impressive specimens at Ardkinglas are the Patagonian cypress, European silver fir and mountain hemlock.ardkinglasAbbotsford, Melrosepound. entry The former home of Sir Walter Scott offers a rare example of a Regency garden, which the novelist designed in consultation with artist and architect friends. It is ided into three interconnecting outdoor rooms: the formal South Court, the sunken Morris garden and the walled garden, the latter of which is entered via a stone archway and contains fruit trees, herbaceous borders and a glass house. Many of the ingredients in its Ochiltreersquos Cafeacute are picked from the walled garden. Spring blooms include narcissi, camassia and puschkinia, and planning is underway for a new mindfulness garden with a water feature as part of celebrations for Sir Walter Scottrsquos th anniversary year.scottsabbotsfordGlenwhan Gardens, StranraerFrom pound.Itrsquos hard to believe when looking at Glenwhanrsquos verdant landscape that its grounds comprised little more than boggy wasteland a few decades ago. Often lauded as Scotlandrsquos most beautul man-made garden, it has been designed around two lochans and has an arboretum with a trail consisting of more than  tree species, a rock garden and a -acremoorland walk through wildflowers, grasses and ferns. Head up to Tessrsquos Lookout for a viewpoint overlooking the gardens and beyond to the Isle of Man, Luce Bay and the Mull of Galloway. Andthe settingrsquos too idyllic for you to leave, thatrsquos fine: the Shepherdrsquos Hut in the garden sleeps two.glenwhangardensAttadale Gardens, Wester Rosspound entry Painter Nicky Macpherson developed Attadale Gardens in the s after storms brought down many of its old trees. It was a chance to hit reset and has been designed with an artistrsquos eye think Monet-style bridges, sculptures, a giant sundial in the sunken garden and a geodesic dome housing one of Scotlandrsquos largest fern collections. A glossy lily pond, man-made waterfall and beds of bog-loving plants can be found in the Water Garden, and the Japanese Garden is a zen space with cloud-pruned azaleas, bamboo and miniature coners. Take a stroll along the rhododendron walk to reach a stone stairway that leads to a viewpoint with outstanding views of the Skye hills.attadalegardensGarden of Cosmic Speculation, DumfriesPrice yet to be announcedOrdinarily this -acresculpture garden at Portrack House would be holding its annual open day this weekend, but this will now take place later in the year at a date yet to be announced. However, it would be remiss of us not to place it on your radar. An al-fresco work of art designed by the late landscape architect Charles Jencks and his we Maggie Keswick Jencks, it encompasses  areas exploring wonders of the cosmos. Stand-out features include a water cascade of steps symbolising the evolution of the universe and a terrace made of Astroturf and aluminium designed to show the distortion of space and time caused by a black hole.gardenofcosmicspeculation

title: british-irish-lions-borders-rugby-stars-2021-squad
story: TWO Borders rugby stars have been included in Warren Gatlandrsquos -man British and Irish Lions squad to face South Africa.Scotland captain Stuart Hogg made the cut, while there was also a first call-up for Rory Sutherland at loosehead prop.Sutherland spoke of his delight at being included, after he dislocated his shoulder against France during the Six Nations.He told The Times: "I was asked to watch it [the announcement] with the team but didnt want to, I wanted to watch it on my own. I watched it on my phone in the car."A groin muscle injury in  left the -year-old bedridden and wonderinghe would be able to continue playing the sport.He added: "Going through that time I wonderedId ever play rugby again."To be in this position now, Im just over the moon. I cant wait to get stuck in."Sutherland will be the th player from Hawick to join a tour.And he is looking forward to representing his town alongside Stuart Hogg.He told The Times: "Hoggy has been on tours already and Im really looking forward to sharing that experience with him."Its a huge jersey to fill and theres a massive history behind it in Hawick."To be able to be part of that is special."Hogg was in contention to captain the squad but that responsibility has been placed on the experienced shoulders of Wales skipper Alun Wyn Jones.The Scots included in the squad are Hogg, Sutherland, Zander Ferguson, Hamish Watson, Ali Price, Finn Russell, Chris Harris and Duhan van der Merwe.Gatland announced the full squad to play in the series against South Africa this summer at .pm on Thursday . title: rachael-hamilton-paul-wheelhouse-election-result-2021
story: RACHAEL Hamilton says she is ldquoabsolutely ecstatic after being re-elected as the MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire.Mrs Hamilton, of the Scottish Conservatives, received , votes in the Scottish Parliament contest, while runner-up Paul Wheelhouse from the SNP recorded ,.Mrs Hamilton, who won the by-election, will nowto Holyrood as theconstituency representative.Important to protect jobsAfter the result was declared, Mrs Hamilton told the Border : ldquoI think this is fantastic."It speaks volumes of the work my team have done and the support for the Scottish Conservatives in the Borders.ldquoI think the voters in the Borders have rejected what could have been Nicola Sturgeon calling for a hard border at Berwick. Itrsquos really important that we focus now on rebuilding the economy and looking after peoplersquos livelihoods and their incomes.ldquoItrsquos important that we protect jobs and we ensure that the NHS can get back on its feet after all this time that it has had to focus on the pandemic. There are people out there who have had cancelled operations and theyrsquore waiting for them.ldquoItrsquoll be my focus that we ensure that we just get back to normal and we concentrate on that and not a border or independence."I want to end the isionAsked what her priority for the region is, Mrs Hamilton said: ldquoMy main focus is to end the ision and work towards rebuilding the Borders. Itrsquos very dficult to do anything  other than to rebuild an economy and protect jobs.ldquoI think itrsquos important to look after young people and their education because obviously therersquos a massive catch-up exercise that needs to be done because kids havenrsquot had face-to-face learning, theyrsquove been learning from home. Theyrsquore only just back at school.ldquoThere are young people who are going to have suffered from the fact that they havenrsquot had that face-to-face learning and I think itrsquos important that we resource our schools to ensure that those kids can catch up.Wheelhouse disappointedMr Wheelhouse also spoke to the Border after the declaration.He said:ldquoIrsquom obviously disappointed because I dearly wanted to represent this constituency, but I congratulate Rachael for her win.ldquoI take comfort from the fact that our vote has increased. Itrsquos the largest number of votes wersquove had in this seat and the largest share of the votes wersquove had in this seat so thatrsquos encouraging, but clearly I wanted to win so Irsquom disappointed in that.ldquoIrsquom pleased for the activists that we got an increase in the votes for all their efforts.ldquoItrsquos a small swing but itrsquos signicant that wersquore still on the up. Irsquove yet to see what the pattern is across the country, we know that wersquove got a tough task here in terms of the constitutional question causes a polarisation in the electorate.ldquoMaybe people are voting on constitutional grounds rather than necessarily who they think could be the best representative for the area.Wersquore not going awayReflecting on the campaign, Mr Wheelhouse said: ldquoWersquoll keep plugging away, being positive. We put across a really positive campaign which Irsquom very proud of.ldquoWe didnrsquot focus on attacking the opposition, we focused on showing what we could do for the area and I hope that might inspire some ideas for others to pick up.ldquoI just hope that Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire gets good representation for the next five years, it does deserve it.ldquoI hope for this constituencyrsquos sake that Rachael can step up to the plate and can do that but wersquoll certainly still be around.ldquoWersquore not going away. If she fails wersquoll be looking to take the seat next time.

title: election-snp-candidate-christine-grahame-wins-seat
story: CHRISTINE Grahame from the Scottish National Partyhas been elected as the MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale following the  Scottish Parliament election.Voters in Scotland went to the polls on Thursday , with counts held across the country yesterday and today .After ballot papers were totted up in Kelso today, Ms Grahame was declared the victor in her constituency. She won the previous Holyrood contest in .This time round, Ms Grahame received a total of , votes - up from , in .Second place has gone toScottish Conservative candidate Shona Haslam .In Ms Grahames victory speech, she sent a message to Prime Minister Boris Johnson.She said: ldquoI would like to say this to the electoratehellip Isnrsquot it wonderful to have such a turnout across Scotland for a Scottish Parliament election ldquoWhether you have voted for me or not, as I have done for the last times I have been elected, I will work for you no matter how you voted.ldquoAnd I know that is true of all the MSPs in the Scottish Parliament. Wersquore not partisan, any of us, when wersquore working for our constituents.ldquoAcross Scotland, I want to say thishellip First of all, this is the best constituency in Scotland,not the entire world.ldquoAnd the second thing I want to say about the vote is thishellip We will have, for the fourth term, an SNP government. And that is extraordinary.ldquoSecondly, there will be a majority in that parliament who have voted for people to have a choice that is to have a referendum, at an appropriate time, on whether or not Scotland becomes an independent country.ldquoAnd I want to say this to Boris Johnsonhellip What is the democratic way for the Scottish people to voice their will, other thanto go to the ballot box and, with proportional representation,a majority of MSPs who want a referendum ldquoIf that is not the way to do it, Boris, you tell us the way to do it.RESULTS:Christine Grahameshyndash ,.Shona Haslamndash ,.Katherine Sangsterndash ,AC Mayndash ,Dominic Ashmolendash ,Michael James Banksndash

title: selkirk-seven-new-shops-open-amid-business-boom-town
story: A BORDERS townis said to be experiencing a ldquorenaissance, with seven new shops having thrown open their doors recently.A iety of stores have joined the high street in Selkirk, some of them offering products and services previously not found in the town.A spokesperson for Explore Selkirk said: ldquoSelkirk is going through a renaissance, and the town has a real feeling of optimism.ldquoWhilst other high streets have struggled to keep shops open during the pandemic, Selkirk has seen seven new shops open in the town centre.The Border toured the town with Explore Selkirk, meeting the business owners.Many were upbeat about launching during the pandemic.Number One deli. Photo: Phil WilkinsonldquoTo be honest, it probably couldnrsquot have happened at a better time, said Tracey Ward, who runs Number One delicatessen with her husband Trevor.She added: ldquoSome folk thought we were mad opening up in the middle of a pandemic but itrsquos been really good ndash in fact wersquove been able to concentrate on it as well.The couple also own The Fleece Bar and Kitchen in the town.Trevor added: ldquoWersquove been open eight weeks now. We were well supported by the local community when the first lockdown came.ldquoTherersquos a lot of good will out there and wersquore thankful for that.The Peony Rose Coffee House. Photo: Phil WilkinsonCatherine Inglis took over the Selkirk Deli and renamed it the Peony Rose Coffee House.She offered on-the-door takeaways before being allowed to welcome guests indoors last week.Catherine said: ldquoItrsquos been a challenge.ldquoBut Irsquove been very lucky as Irsquove had the opportunity to get it how I want.ldquoEvery cloud has a silver lining.For some local residents, searching for tools and DIY items use to mean having to travel to shops in other Borders towns now, however, shoppers looking for lightbulbs, tools and even pet supplies can find them closer to home at Ideal Hardware  Home Essentials.Lorna Han is the owner of the store, which opened in October.She told this newspaper: ldquoBusiness has been steady, wersquove been well supported.Meanwhile, on Market Place, The General Storerepairs broken items and sells upcycled goods.The General Store. Photo: Phil WilkinsonFounded by Sue Briggs and Dot Torrance, the repair shop has been operating since before Christmas - but the retail side of The General Store has only just opened.The teamrsquos ethos is that damage doesnrsquot make something useless.ldquoSomething can be beautul evenitrsquos damaged, Sue said.They hope that by offering repair services, as well as selling beautul upcycled items made by local creators, they can start a conversation about eco-friendly living and making the most of what we have now.Basanti India. Photo: Phil WilkinsonBasanti India ndash which sells ethically sourced gts and accessories and did have a temporary presence in the town ndash has now moved to permanent premises.Owner Imogen Kennedy told us: ldquoI lived in India for  years I know all my providers.ldquoI started in the pop-up on Tower Street ndash itrsquos a great launch pad.ldquoItrsquos really nice to have a permanent place on the high street.Skinnys. Photo: Phil WilkinsonAnd for anyone with a sweet tooth, Skinnyrsquos on Market Place serves waffles, ice-cream and a range of lunchtime snacks.Co-owner Shirley Singhtoor said: ldquoWersquove had lots of interest.ldquoWe just want to spread the word and see how things go.Burnside Gallery. Photo: Phil WilkinsonAlso newly opened is the Burnside Gallery and Frames, run by Javier Ternero and Charly Murray.They said: ldquoSelkirk has been wonderful, very welcoming. Therersquos a ersity of businesses here.For more information on the range of businesses in Selkirk, you can visit: exploreselkirk

title: asda-announce-major-changes-coming-every-uk-store
story: Asda has published its first environmental, social and governancereport and with it promised changes affecting every store in the UK.The supermarket giant has set out its commitments to a sustainable business strategy in the future.The report interviewed , customers and found that shoppers had three priorities.According to the report, customers want more affordable greener choices, commitments to reduce single-use plastic and cutting food waste.The supermarket said it is now committed to becoming a net zero carbon business by .Asda ndash one of the UKrsquos big six UK supermarket retailers ndash will join rivals such as Sainsburyrsquos and Aldi in becoming more environmentally friendly.Asda bosses plan to remove three billion pieces of plastic from products within the next four years.They also want to ensure its top  commodities, including cotton and cocoa, are sustainably sourced by .The chain has also pledged to increase the proportion of own-brand products that are low in fat, sugar and salt to % by .Roger Burnley, Asda CEO and President, said:ldquoAsda has always been a retailer that sits at the heart of the communities it serves and the events of the last  months have highlighted the important role we play in helping to tackle societal challenges.ldquoDespite the challenges of the pandemic, we have not lost sight of our wider ESG responsibilities and this report provides an update of where Asda is now on the issues that matter most to our colleagues, customers and communities and importantly where we want to be in the future."It builds upon our existing create change for better commitments and the resilience we have shown during the last  months means we are well positioned to help customers make greener, healthier and responsible choices when they shop with us.

title: 20mph-limits-scottish-borders-council-starts-consultation
story: BORDERS residents can now have their say on the mph speed trial which began last year.As part of the Spaces for People programme, the reduced limit was introduced in more than  towns and villages in the region.And todayan online consultation has been launched, so people can share their views on the trial ndash for example, whether they think any roads should change back to mph.Gordon Edgar, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, transport and travel, said: ldquoThe mph trial, which has been in place for the last seven months, was introduced to make it easier and safer for people to walk, cycle and wheel for everyday journeys.ldquoWith it having been in place for a signicant amount of time during the coronavirus pandemic, we now want to get feedback from Borderers as to how effective it has been."As part of the consultation, which will run until June , contributors will be asked how the scheme impacted travel and whether they chose to walk or cycle more as a result.During the trial, data was collected to show how the new limits affected average speeds. The results can be accessed at scottishborders.tracsis-tads conduit bordersOne example is the .mph reduction in average speed at Hillside Terrace, Selkirk .Mr Edgar said: "Whether you are a keen walker or cyclist, have a business which operates in the Borders, live in this part of the country or drive on the roads across the region, I would urge you to feedback your specic experiences with the trial and how it has impacted your travel.ldquoItrsquos important that we get as many responses to this consultation as possible, to help inform any permanent changes the council makes following the trial.ldquoThese will be made purely on an inidual basis, based on the specic needs of each community, the feedback we receive through the consultation and the impartial data collected across theof the trial.The consultations findings will be reported later this year, detailing which parts of the scheme will be kept ndashany.Cyclists, pedestrians, residents, business owners and drivers are all asked to contribute to the consultation.To share your views, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk mphThe speed limits were introduced by Scottish Borders Council, working with the Scottish Government, Transport Scotland and Sustrans.

title: covid-scotland-rules-meeting-inside-home
story: From next Monday you will be allowed to meet another household inside your own home for the first time this year.All council areas in Scotlandare expected to move from level three to at leastlevel two from Monday, May .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.These changes will mean that you will be allowed to meet indoors, including homes, as long as you stick to the restrictions.Heres what you need to know:Meeting in homesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially in a home is fourwhich can be from twohouseholds, including for overnight stays.Children under the age of  do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoorsChildren under  do not need to maintain physical distance from others.When you meet people from another household indoors you should:Minimise the number of meetings you have with people from other households each day.Stay at least twometres apart from anyone who is not part of your household.Maintain hand and cough hygiene.Avoid touching hard surfaces with your hands.Wash your hands when you arrive, when you leave, when you get home and especially before eating or after touching surfaces.Not sharing food or utensils.Keep rooms well ventilated,possible ndash consider opening windows or a door.

title: michael-gove-makes-scottish-borders-council-comment-bbc
story: THE leader of Scottish Borders Councilsays she was ldquodelighted to hear Michael Goversquos comments on the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show.When Mr Marr interviewed the Minister for the Cabinet Office on Sunday , Mr Gove suggested the UK Government is keen to work closely with local authorities in Scotland ndash including SBC.SBC leader Shona Haslam, also of the Conservatives, said: "I am absolutely delighted that the UK Government will be supporting councils in this way."When Mr Gove was interviewed, he said that as part of the UK Governmentrsquos lsquoLevelling Uprsquo project, Whitehall could work directly with Scottish councils to provide funding.When asked by Mr Marrthese plans were aiming to bypass the Scottish Government and put the Scottish Parliament "back in its box", Mr Gove said: "Certainly not."We want to work with both."I think its critically important we work with the Scottish Government and with local government as well."We have already seen opportunities to do just that."When we announced that we were going to work with both Holyrood, but also local authorities, I think it was the leader of Glasgow council ndash an SNP politician ndash who welcomed that, along with the leaders of Aberdeen council, Borders council and so on."To my mind, its an example of Team UK working together in everyones interests."lsquoLevelling Uprsquo is a Westminster White Paper, to be published later this year, which "will focus on challenges including improving living standards, growing the private sector and increasing and spreading opportunity".Mrs Haslam told the Border : "I am very excited about the opportunity to work with the UK Government on funding proposals and have already had several useful meetings with our MPs for this area and the Scotland Office.ldquoI would encourage anyone with ideas for local projects to contact their local councillor to discuss options.

story: All council areas in Scotlandwill move to Level  on Monday,with the possible exception of Moray which will stay in Level  and several islands will move to Level .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK have said the threat level should be lowered from "level "to "level ", thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Here is what you can and cannot do in Level  lockdown:Can I meet peopleinside my home Yes but the maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Social distancing rules do not need to be followed.Can I get a pint or a meal indoors Yes. title: glasgow-science-centre-free-attend-innovation-event
story: Glasgow Science Centre is holding its second online festival - May, and everyone aged  and upwards is invited to attend.Curious About Innovation will celebrate the innovative spirit in all of us, and how that spirit can change the world.The three-day programme of live talks, interviews, games and resources will reveal how technology and innovation are solving global challenges. The festival is being delivered with support from the Inspiring Science Fund provided by Wellcome, UKRI and BEIS with additional support from JP Morgan, Mathworks and University of Strathclyde.Top innovators from Scotlandand around the world have signed up to take part. Experts from organisations like Rolls Royce, AAC Clyde Space, the National Oceanographic Centre, IBM and the Scottish Space School have all signed up.NASA astronauts and engineers will be beamed in from the USA to answer questions about le in space the Royal Navy will take everyone on a guided tour round a virtual submarine and the plans to get oysters cleaning the Clyde will be revealed.The festival is free and open to everyone, just register on https:curiousabout.glasgowsciencecentre.org .Click image to attend for freeStephen Breslin, chief executive of Glasgow Science Centre, said: ldquoCurious About Innovation has been designed to entertain and inspire everyone aged  and upwards.ldquoSome of the worldrsquos most exciting science and technology will be showcased in the festival. It will cover industries like space, construction, cyber security, health, robotics and the environment.ldquoThe festival will inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers by highlighting the career paths and employers that are available to young people in Scotland.Curious About Innovation is Glasgow Science Centrersquos second online festival. It builds on the themes connected with GSCrsquos IdeaNo exhibition, which everyone can visit in person when the science centre reopens.The festival also supports GSC Learning Labrsquos space module and GSCrsquos STEMFuturesrsquo programme, which is helping thousands of young people into STEM work experience and career choices.Curious About Innovation is free to everyone, but those aged  and upwards will get the most out of it. Visit https:curiousabout.glasgowsciencecentre.org for updates.Click image to attend for freeCurious About Innovation: HighlightsScotlandrsquos innovation in the space sector ,  May, -The space sector is booming in Scotland. Join AAC Clyde Space to find out about innovation and growth in the space sector and how we use satellites to communicate and collect information.NASA live talks,  May,    May, Join NASA engineers and astronauts as they give you the lowdown on living in space, and keeping astronauts comfortable and safe on orbit. Youll even have the opportunity to ask questions about their exciting careers.Virtual Submarine Tour with the Royal Navy,  May,  ndash Take a virtual tour of a Navy submarine, go behind the scenes and learn about the innovations and the practical engineering solutions within the vessel.Construction Innovation with Morrison Construction,  May,  ndash Take a virtual tour of a construction site, see how Morrison Construction uses the latest innovation and technology to design buildings on their sites. title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-covid-rules-set-ease
story: Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that most of Scotland will enter Level  lockdown next week.People in Scotland will be able to hugged loved ones again from Monday ndash subject to restrictions ndash an emotional Nicola Sturgeon has said as she confirmed further lockdown easing.These changes will include meeting up to six people from three households socialising indoorsrestaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening andquarantine-free international travel.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a "consistent"fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.Heres what you need to know:Scotland to enter Level The First Minister confirmed that the majority of Scotland will move to Level  lockdown from May .Moray will stay in Level and the Scottish Islands will move to Level  from Monday.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Household changesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six people which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Hugs are back!Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed that hugs will be allowed indoors in Scotland.The First Minister said: "From Monday,you are meeting friends and family, within the permitted limits of course, either indoors in a private dwelling or in your garden, our guidance will say that it is no longer necessary to maintain physical distance."Which means - and I actually feel a bit emotional as I say this - that from Monday, as long as you stay within permitted limits, you can hug your loved ones again."I know how desperate we all are for this - and so I donrsquot intend to immediately pour cold water on it - but there are two further points I really need to make."She added: "Close physical contact does still carry risk, I have to be clear about that."Soyou have loved ones who are vulnerable for any reason, please still be careful. And limit the overall number of people that you choose to have close physical contact with."Moray decisionNicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will not move to Level  and will stay in Level  for a "further period".The decision comes as health authorities in the area are currently dealing with "uncontrolled, sustained community transmission"of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of Scotland.Travel restrictions willbe brought into Moray and people should only enter there for essential purposes only.Ms Sturgeon said: "In recent days, as you will have seen, Moray has been experiencing a high and increasing number of cases with a small associated increase in hospital admissions."Indeed, public health experts consider that Moray is currently experiencing widespread community transmission."She added: "It is therefore highly probable that Moray will stay at level  for a further period."It is also important that we take precautions to reduce the risk of the transmission of Covid spreading from Moray to other parts of Scotland, as restrictions ease where.""SoMoray does stay in level  - which will be finally decided at the end of the week - we will also reimpose travel restrictions for a hopefully short period.This will mean that travel in and out of Moray will be limited to permitted purposes only."Islands changesMany islands in Scotland will move to Level  due to low case numbers.Nicola Sturgeon said:"For our island communities, the situation is dferent and much more positive."Case numbers have consistently been at very low levels for some time now."Many islands also now have very good vaccination coverage, and lateral flow tests are available for all people travelling to the islands from other parts of Scotland."For those reasons, we have decided that it is possible to ease restrictions more quickly for communities in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney for all islands in Highland, except Skye, given its fixed link and for the Inner Hebrides islands in Argyll - including Islay, Jura and Mull."All of these areas will move directly to level  from Monday, rather than to level ."International TravelPeople in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Nicola Sturgeon said: "At the outset, let me be very clear that we still intend to be highly cautious on international travel - given the risk of new iants - but we consider that the situation now allows us to begin a careful move away from blanket restrictions on non-essential travel."From Monday, we will move to a traffic light system, informed by risk assessments prepared by the Joint Biosecurity Centre. These assessments will be based on the state of the pandemic in each country across the world - including the presence of iants of concern."These green countries include:PortugalIsraelSingaporeAustraliaNew ZealandBruneiIcelandGibraltarFalkland IslandsFaroe IslandsSouth Georgia and the Sandwich IslandsSt Helena, Tristan de Cunh and Ascension IslandLatest case numbersThe First Minister was unable to update on the latest Covid numbers due to "IT issues".Nicola Sturgeon said:"I hope that will be resolved soon, and I can assure you that all of todays figures will be published just as quickly as possible."Youll be able to access them when theyre published on the Scottish Government website."
