title: i-got-politics-make-difference-bank-balance---david-camerons-week
story: I HAVE to say, first of all,I may, that the claims being made that Irsquom dodgier than a Kelvin Hall dodgem being driven by Roger the Dodger in the direction of Dodge City are entirely without foundation.As I told the select committees, all I did was work for a money lending firm that planned to pay off chemists owed money by HM Treasury, and charge the government exorbitant rates of interests for the privilege.Is setting up this deal in any way dodgy Yes, I may have sent  texts, or begging messagesyou wish to be accurate, and yes, I signed off lsquoLove, DC.rsquo But I sign off all my texts this way ndash which perhaps explains why the young man delivering the Dominorsquos pizza to my Chipping Norton door on a Friday night has an expectant smile on his face.The reality is Irsquove been trying to help the economy recover from the pandemic, working for the public goodyou like. Remember, as an ex-politician I am now a fully paid-up member of the public, which means I should do nothing but good for me, given half the chance.Now, Labours Angela Eagle tried to embarrass me about the text begging, which was laughable. I hardly blushed when it was claimed I inserted my private members bill into a pigrsquos mouth during my Oxford initiation ceremony.I once shrugged off the gaffe I made about Nigeria being fantastically corrupt, thus compromising the Queen. And there was Brexit, of course, which would have caused other PMs to hide away in an ancestral croft in Uist.I donrsquot have a shiny face for nothing, you know. Irsquom more oil than Olay. But letrsquos not forget the really important issue here why is it wrong to try and pull a few favours worth, allegedly, poundm, from friends  And why is it wrong of me to disguise this  As a PR man, I know all about obfuscation.Back in , I was asked in an interview how many houses I owned. I said I didnrsquot know. SoIrsquom not going to answer a simple question about whether I knew Lex Greensillrsquos banking scheme was always headed for the sewage pond, unless I lovebombed Rishi Sunak into flashing the cash OK, Herald readers want to know why I got into politics in the first place  Well, the truth is I wanted to make a dference. Do I mean a dference to my bank account  All I can say is Irsquove long known that influence is worth way more than the measly poundk a PM makes. And have you any idea how much I love private plane flights, and houses, however many there may be But I will admit I regret this investigation business  I regret sending texts. Irsquod have been better making fly phone calls instead. And I do admit I want to be loved. And not just by pizza boys.lsquoLove, DC,rsquo really is the real me.

title: coronavirus-glasgow-inquiry-rigged-vaccine-shifts
story: It is alleged a group of eight employees used bots ndash computer software that performs repetitive tasks ndash to book multiple shts atthe NHS Louisa Jordan Hospitalin Glasgow as soon as they were advertised.Some are said to have passed on shts to colleagues during the scam, which is said to have been going on for months.At one point, pharmacists could expect to earn up to pound for a -hour sht, the same rate as doctors and dentists.ldquoAnyone who has gamed the system is beneath contempt.NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde confirmed it is investigating ldquoanomalies in the booking system.The British Dental Association claimed the booking scandal and vaccine supply issues had led to dentists in Glasgow struggling to secure shts.: Glasgow to remain in level three as areas experience spike in casesRobert Donald, chairman of the BDArsquos Scottish Council, called for an investigation ldquowith no stone unturned and added: ldquoAnyone who has gamed the system is beneath contempt.The BDA has suggested the situation in Glasgow contributed to a decision to downgrade pharmacist payments, but this has been denied by the Scottish Government.Pharmacist shts rates were changed in late March frompound per .-hour sht to Band  rates of pound per hour due to a ldquomisunderstanding over contract guidelines, but the change did not affect dentists and doctors.About  pharmacists were registered to provide vaccinations but the pay change is said to have led to lower uptake and a shortage of vaccinators.According to the BDA, dentistsin Glasgow were sent text messages yesterday afternoon urging them to help out with immunisations but most were unable to assist because they were in practice.: Clinically vulnerable patients among those waiting  weeks for Covid boosterThe NHS Louisa Jordan Hospital closed at the end of March, with mass vaccinations moved toThe Hydro.The BDA said it had been seeking urgent talks with the Scottish Government about shts availability but said discussions were delayed due to pre-election purdah rules.A spokeswoman for NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said: "We would like to thank all those involved in the highly successful rollout of the vaccination programme across NHSGGC.ldquoWe have a large bank of staff vaccinators to call on.ldquoWe have been made of aware of some anomalies in the way some shts were being booked and these are currently under investigation. Shts are made available to all vaccinators to book at the same time.ldquoStrict security and identication protocols are in place at NHS Louisa Jordan for all staff entering the building.The Herald contacted the union that represents pharmacists ndash The Pharmacistsrsquo Defence Association ndash but no one responded to our request for comment.It is the latest row to engulf Scotlandrsquos Covid vaccinationstaskforce.In March, nurses complained they had been left feeling ldquohacked off and undervalued when they discovered that independent contractor colleagues were being paid nearly five times as much.The discrepancy arose out of a misunderstanding around the term ldquoindependent contractor.: Hospitality sector hits out at Scottish Government after Glasgow level freezeThe pound per session rate was originally agreed by the Scottish Government as a payment to independent enterprises such as pharmacies ndash which contracttheir services to the NHS ndash to compensate them for giving up a member of their team to workpart-time at vaccination hubs.The rate was never intended tobe paid on an inidual basis to locums, who have no overheads or business costs.However, the message became confused as vaccinator recruitment was devolved to health boards and locum pharmacists, dentists, optometrists and GPs began being hired as ldquoindependent contractors on pound per session.The Scottish Government intervened to correct the arrangement after community pharmacy owners complained of staff shortages as locum pharmacists cancelled shts to work as vaccinators instead.Locum dentists, GPs, and optometrists are continuing to receive the higher rate, however.Robert Donald chairman of the BDA said: ldquoScotland is ing to something resembling normality thanks to the vaccination programme.ldquoAnyone who has gamed the system is frankly beneath contempt.ldquoWe urge the authorities to leave no stone unturned to uncover the facts at NHS Louisa Jordan.The BDA has suggested a decision to downgrade pharmacist pay rates was linked to booking anomalies in Glasgow.However the Scottish Government denied any suggestion of a link was .

title: outpouring-support-around-world-fans-urge-clarity-glasgow-clan-arena-situation
story: Gareth Chalmers has thanked supporters and clubs around the world for their support following the news that plans for the upcoming season have been put on pause over the future of their arena.The Aspray Glasgow Clan is looking to become the new operating company of the Braehead Arena in a bid to maintain and develop ice hockey in the area. The clubhas entered negotiations with the new owners of Braehead Shopping Centre, Global Mutual.:Save our Glasgow Clan petition nears , signaturesWith the future uncertain with a decision expected in the near future,a petition has collected over , signatures calling for The Clan to be handed over the ice facility at Braehead.It had gathered support from around the world with hockey clubs, players, coaches and more all backing the club.Chalmers told The Herald: ldquoThe support has been fantastic, wersquove had people and clubs contacting us through the hockey world offering their support. Itrsquos been overwhelming at times, it really shows how important and respected we are as a hockey club.ldquoIrsquod like to thank the Clan fans for all their support so far, whether thatrsquos been via phone calls, emails, texts, on social media. The support has been phenomenal and absolutely fantastic to see."This is so much more than a hockey club, itrsquos a community, itrsquos a happy place, a sanctuary for so many people."We all want the same end result, we all want to see the Clan back on the ice, and we all want an exciting and successful future ndash we can do this together.Our immediate priority on here is # positivity, focused on securing a home for the Clan  our communityPlease Sign the Petition! https:t.co PWEFKQl @ClanIHC @ClanOSC #ClanForTheFutureHe added that the situation regarding the future of the arena has been at the forefront of his planning saying: ldquoWhile we made the situation public last week, the situation has been going on for sometime so Irsquove been extremely busy planning for ious dferent outcomes, pulling information and figures together, while continuing to correspond regarding the situation.Glasgow Clan chief Gareth ChalmersldquoObviously when the news went public, it took everything to the next level, but thatrsquos exactly what we wanted.And fans have been reaching out to show their support for the club and what it means to them.Kerry Russell OSC Secretary and Roddie Brown OSC Chairman said: ldquoWe are all really nervous to hear that there may no longer be ice hockey at Braehead. We hope that we will hear some positive news soon and we can get back to having our brilliant match night experiences watching the Glasgow Clan.ldquoThe Glasgow Clan is a huge economic entity for the area, the players all live locally, staying close to the arena, frequenting local pubs, restaurants.ldquoThere is also the tremendous pocket power of the Purple Army. Most of our supporters spend money on retail, food and drink before and during a typical match night. Losing the ice at Braehead would have a detrimental impact on so many shops and restaurants at the shopping centre.Many fans have been quick to suggest that they will notto Braeheadthe Clan are taken off the ice, with hockey for many being theonly reason to attend. Ross Jardine,  has been a season ticket holder since  and said that he would be unlikely to visit the shopping centre due to his own circumstances. He said: ldquoIf Clan go, I wonrsquot be back in Braehead#ClanForTheFuture letrsquos gooooo Clan fans and hockey fans! Letrsquos get k for the petition and keep hockey where it belong! In Glasgow! pic skYcHiXldquoNot as a boycott but therersquos just nothing in it I canrsquot get closer to home."Irsquom in Falkirk, and I make the trip through to skate every Monday plus whatever Clan gamersquos on. But the shopping in Stirlingrsquos closer and sorsquos their rinkHe added: "Even my barber is a Clan fan. I met him through Clan and drive through to Dennistoun for haircutsDeryck Sellar, , echoed the sentiment that many would not the Clan did notto Braehead. He said: ldquoFans would be crushed and they would no longer have a reason to travel to Braehead Shopping Centre."Some of these fans are coming from as far away as Edinburgh, Falkirk, Troon, and Saltcoatsand they choose to bypass local options to go spend their money in Braehead because theyrsquore either there for Clan games or they have a sense of loyalty to Braehead.ldquoHowever,you remove Clan as a factor then these fans will have no reason to come to Braehead because they have locations much closer to them where they would go and spend their money.Clan fan Sarah Barbour,  said: ldquoI donrsquot do well in crowds but at Clan games, its almost like Im having too much fun to even notice how many people are actually there. The atmosphere and buzz of the whole of Braehead on game day is something you cant compare to anything .:Le on ice: How Glasgow Clan have rallied to prepare for post-shutdownldquoThey really do mean it when they say hockey is for everyone. I just hope that the Purple Army never stop making noise about this because the arena is so important to so many people from players to fans to volunteersFormer season ticket holder Lesley MacGregor, , said that her -year-old son Tom only started playing hockey from going to Clan matches. She said: ldquoIt will be so sadwe lose The Clan ice hockey in Glasgow, I gave up our season tickets just last year as my sons games are on at the same time, butit hadnrsquot been for the Clan he wouldnrsquot be playingLong-time fan Aidan Brysland, , added:ldquoClan are so much more than just a hockey club, we are a community and a family and I hope that with the current uncertainty around the arena that Global Mutual can see just how much The Clan brings to the community in Renfrewshire and even beyond.Last week a spokesperson for Global Mutual said: ldquoWe are committed to finding the best possible solution to ensure the long-term viability of the Braehead Arena. Our team is currently evaluating proposals from a number of interested parties and we will communicate our decision as soon as possible, most likely by the end of this month.You can sign the petition HERE

story: Labour has urged Cabinet Secretary Simon Case to investigate the Home Secretary over suggestions she attempted to sway the award of a contract after being approached by a Tory activist.:Boris Johnsons Mustique holiday was worth double the amount he declaredThe Daily Mail reported that Ms Patel lobbied Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove in April last year during efforts to secure the contract for Pharmaceuticals Direct Limited .Her efforts were said to have failed after Health Secretary Matt Hancock decided the masks were ldquonot suitable for the NHS.But PDL was awarded a pound. million contract weeks later in July to provide a dferent type of mask, during which Samir Jassal was also the contact.Mr Jassal has stood as a Conservative candidate at two general elections and has met Boris Johnson and David Cameron.A spokesman for Ms Patel: ldquoThe Home Secretary rightly followed up representations made to her about the vital supply of PPE.ldquoDuring a time of national crisis, failure to do so would have been a dereliction of duty.However, Labour urged the Cabinet Secretary to investigate Ms Patel in a letter signed by deputy leader Angela Rayner and shadow home secretary Nick Thomas-Symonds.They said there is ldquono evidence that the Home Secretary had any interest in the PPE deal until contacted by Mr Jassal, suggesting she did it ldquoas a favour to her friend.ldquoThis would represent a glaring and flagrant breach of the ministerial code, they said.They pointed to the principle that ldquoministers must ensure that no conflict arises, or could reasonably be perceived to arise, between their public duties and their private interests, financial or otherwise.Last year the ministerial standards adviser found Ms Patelrsquos conduct ldquoamounted to behaviour that can be described as bullying but the Prime Minister overruled the finding as ultimate arbiter of the code.:Kevin McKenna: There is a simple reason why Glasgow stood up to the Home Office gangstersThe Government already faced possible legal action over the pound. million contract from the Good Law Project as it investigates how coronavirus contracts were awarded.Jolyon Maugham, director of the campaign, said: ldquoWhy did Jassal, a man connected to past and present Tory PMs, ministers and peers, reach out to Priti Patel for help ldquoWhat was his role in winning the pound million contract  What relationship did his connections with the party have to the pound million contract won by Pharmaceuticals Direct ldquoThese are the questions at the heart of our judicial review of this most troubling of PPE contracts.Mr Jassal and PDL have been contacted for comment.

title: charity-considers-legal-action-home-office-glasgow-immigration-raid
story: Lakhvir Singh and Sumit Sehdev were released from Border Force detention after crowds swarmed around the van in which they were held, preventing it from leaving Kenmure Street in Pollokshields on Thursday.Demonstrators blocked the vehicle for several hours, with one even lying underneath its axles, before police released the pair on public safety grounds.Scottish Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf has blamed the Home Office for its ldquoreckless action, while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has attacked its ldquoappalling asylum and immigration policy.Mr Singh and Mr Sehdev, both aged in their s and reportedly a mechanic and chef respectively, have lived in the UK for several years and are ldquopart of a community, said refugee and migrant charity Positive Action in Housing.:Kenmure Street: Nicola Sturgeon says Home Office must ask itself hard questionsThe charityrsquos director Robina Qureshi said: ldquoThe Home Office have referred to these men as illegal.ldquoWell they are wrong, and we are now investigating legal action against the Home Office for casting such aspersions.ldquoThe term illegal in this context is part of the hostile environment. Itrsquos not appropriate to use it for people who have lived in the UK for several years and are part of a community.ldquoThe men now have legal representation and are in the process of trying to regularise their status.ldquoThe fact that they had no active legal representation before means they were left vulnerable.:Priti Patel accused of breaching ministerial code over PPE lobbyingJelina Berlow Rahman, a lawyer instructed to represent Mr Singh, said he has been in the country since  and ldquohas a right to a private le, a family le.She added: ldquoIt was evident the number of people who came together, that was his community, that was neighbours, that was his friends ndash the majority of people knew him.Ms Qureshi added: ldquoDawn raid vans have no place going into communities dragging innocent people from their homes. They are not, categorically not, criminals.The Home Office has been contacted for comment.On Thursday, a spokeswoman said: ldquoThe UK Government is tackling illegal immigration and the harm it causes, often to the most vulnerable people, by removing those with no right to be in the UK.ldquoThe operation in Glasgow was conducted in relation to suspected immigration offences and the two Indian nationals complied with officers at all times.ldquoThe UK Government continues to tackle illegal migration in all its forms and our New Plan for Immigration will speed up the removal of those who have entered the UK illegally.

title: new-100-days-hope-campaign-offers-scotland-chance-shine-host-cop26
story: SCOTLANDrsquoS time to shine has arrived. With much of the world now emerging from lockdown restrictions imposed by the Covid- pandemic, attentions are once again focusing on Glasgow in anticipation of world leaders reaching agreement on an even more cataclysmic threat to our speciesrsquo survival ndash climate change.With the vast majority of scientists in agreement that global carbon emissions must be drastically reduced within the next few years, COP offers its  participating nations a vital opportunity to unite against this universal threat ndash with Scotland poised to lead from the front as an inspiring example of a small country punching well above its weight when it comes to ushering in a carbon-free future.Since its foundation in ,The Herald has told Scotlands story as it built an unrivalled global reputation for innovation, progressive thinking and trailblazing invention.And now,  Days of Hope will continue to share the countryrsquos inspirational journey with the world, offering a bespoke  for the many visionary businesses, charities, organisations, social enterprises and inspirational iniduals across the country who are busy laying the foundations for a new Scotland where countless future generations can thrive and prosper.The impact of these efforts to reduce carbon emissions will undoubtedly be our generationrsquos legacy for the ages, and with  Days of Hope, The Herald aims to highlight our commitment to the task of chronicling Scotlandrsquos journey to Net Zero for posterity. To achieve this, we are now appealing for the countrys most progressive businesses, organisations and iniduals ndash including community groups and charities ndash to take part in the new campaign, which will culminate with the publication of an official lsquoDeclaration of Hopersquo.This historic document, detailing the inspirational stories of all who took part in  Days of Hope, will then be passed onto officials in Africa ndash who will host the next COP summit.With the Scottish Governmentrsquos Climate Change Plan outlining the countryrsquos ambitous proposals for a % reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by  and Net Zero by , unity across all Scotlandrsquos public and private sectors is essentialthese targets are to be met in time.Yet with COP being heralded as the most important gathering on climate change since the Paris Agreement in , there has clearly never been a better time for the country to unite on the issue ndash with the unrivalled reach The Heraldrsquos print and digital s being fully utilised to help achieve this national consensus on how to reach Net Zero.Herald editor-in-chief Donald Martin said: ldquoHosting COP is a truly momentous occasion for Scotland and offers all of us an opportunity to play our part in reducing carbon emissions and working towards the target of Net Zero by .ldquoThe Herald is proud to launch the  Days of Hope campaign which will focus our minds on the task ahead while also shining a well-deserved spotlight on the many achievements and innovations accomplished so far by trailblazing businesses, groups and iniduals throughout the country.The Heraldrsquos commercial director David Ward said: ldquoFor many years, The Herald has enjoyed the privileged position of launching campaigns and initiatives that have impacted change. It has been particularly exciting to provide a  that showcases the stakeholders, firms and organisations that innovate, inspire and seek to drive behavioural change on such an important issue.ldquoIrsquom extremely proud of what we have achieved to date with these campaigns and look forward to the continued opportunity to be a source of inspiration as the eyes of the entire world fall upon Glasgow and Scotland.Herald business team manager Stephen McTaggart, who conceived the new campaign, said: ldquoI wanted to launch the  Days of Hope campaign as an open  for everyone to participate.ldquoItrsquos a celebration of how far Scotland has come, telling the story of a journey that will hopefully serve as a shining light to the rest of the world on how we have committed to a more sustainable future.

title: how does orkney connect michael faraday and mrs beetons cookbook
story: By Patricia LongThanks to the internet, it is now possible to put together stories of how Orcadians have influenced the wider world.This leads to all sorts of surprising connections, and I did a series of them for BBC Radio Orkney several years ago. This is an extended version of one of them.Michael Faraday was one of the world‚Äôs greatest scientists.He was also one of the first to recognise the importance of reaching a wider audience and he had the perfect venue for this, at the Royal Institution in London. The lecture theatre there is probably the most famous in the world, thanks to the Christmas Lectures he began in , which have been televised since . It was designed by an Orcadian, Thomas Webster.Thomas‚Äôs father Alexander was English, but his mother Mary was the daughter of Thomas Baikie, the minister at St Magnus Cathedral, and Thomas grew up in Orkney.According to his entry in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, he attended Kirkwall Grammar School, and then went to Aberdeen University in , where ‚Äúhe assisted Professor Patrick Copland, a populariser of science.‚Äù Professor Copland was a pioneer of public education, whose extramural classes ran from  to . He also pioneered the use of demonstrations in his lectures, so Thomas may have taken a few new ideas with him when he went to London.Thomas Webster enrolled at the Royal Academy Schools in London as an architectural student in , and had his own business by . He began ‚Äúa school for mechanics,‚Äù and this came to the attention of Count Rumford, one of the founders of what became the Royal Institution. Rumford‚Äôs aim was to encourage the use of mechanical inventions and improvements, and to encourage ‚Äúthe Application of Science to the Common Purposes of Le.‚ÄùAt the age of , Webster was engaged as treasurer and secretary of the Institution and, as Clerk of Works, superintended the transformation of a house into a suitable building. In January , he was told to prepare plans for a new lecture room. Many years later he wrote:The theatre of the Royal Institution is pronounced to be the most perfect room of the kind in the kingdom for possessing the properties of allowing the lecturer to be well heard and seen by the audience and for affording them easy entrance and exit, c . . . it has been stated by Faraday, in his late examination before a committee of the House of Commons, to be ‚Äòalmost perfect as a lecture room,‚Äô and that ‚Äòalthough architects are continually measuring and drawing it to copy from, and many other rooms have been built in imitation of it in which he has tried his voice, yet none of them proved equal to that in question.Sir Humphrey Davy was the first scientist to draw crowds to the lecture theatre, which could seat  people. He also made good use of the laboratory which Thomas Webster had installed, using electrolysis to discover sodium and potassium. Webster wrote later: ‚ÄúThe chemical laboratory in which so many valuable discoveries have been made was not only designed and built by me, but owes to me its very existence, for, though I inserted it in my plans, the managers did not at first consider it necessary.‚ÄùCount Rumford had assured Webster that he was going to establish a science school for workmen and, as he wrote to a friend:It was through the prospect of being employed in this way, which would have been as agreeable to my habits of thinking as useful to my interest, that I was induced to give up the school which I then kept and the other business in which I was engaged, and to accept of a situation and salary in the Institution by no means equivalent to what I should have considered myself as entitled to under other circumstances.Eighty years before compulsory education, he had found that new techniques in building needed better-educated workmen.Knowing from previous experience what it was possible to effect in their improvement, I conceived the idea of giving to mechanics for this purpose a species of scientic education suited to their condition, and I believe I was the first person in this country who took active steps for effecting so desirable an object. I was not unacquainted with the political feelings of that time, but I did not think a little learning was a dangerous thingjudiciously bestowed . . . My idea was to make good mechanics, not to force them like hot-bed plants out of the sphere in which they are so useful.Webster succeeded in convincing the managers that the school was a good idea. News of the school was published, and was very well received. Sadly, after all the preparations were made, ideas changed.I was asked rudely what I meant by instructing the lower classes in science. I was told likewise that it was resolved upon that the plan must be dropped as quietly as possible. It was thought to have a dangerous political tendency, and I was told thatI persisted, I would become a marked man!Webster decided to leave the institution and embark on another career, as a landscape artist.This somehow led to work on textbooks and a commission in , to draw one of the first geological maps of England. Geology was a very new science the Geological Society had only been founded in . Sir Henry Englefield, President of the Society, commissioned Webster to survey and draw the geology of the Isle of Wight. This was published in .Ten years later, Webster became the secretary of the Geological Society and curator of its museum. Soon, he was back at the Royal Institution.Notices of lecture courses in the s include Faraday on chemistry and Webster on geology. He gave the Christmas Lectures, ‚Äúsuitable for a juvenile auditory,‚Äù in .University College London was founded in , and Webster became its first professor of geology in .He is described as the first professional geologist, because it was then still seen as a gentleman‚Äôs hobby. Unfortunately, this meant that he was poorly paid and, although he was awarded a government pension of ¬£ a year for services to geology, he had to find other sources of income.For the last ten years of his le, he worked on a commission from Longmans Publishing. The enormous¬† Encyclopedia of Domestic Economy brought together all ‚Äúthe information useful to persons who have to superintend domestic establishments.‚Äù It begins with where to build your house, and goes on to cover everything from the dferent options for heat and light to the preparation of every sort of beverage, from gin to coffee.It is now well known that Isabella Beeton stole material shamelessly for her Book of Household Management, published in .Her main source was Webster‚Äôs Encyclopedia: on the Arrangement of the Kitchen and General Observations, on beverages, bread, etc. Thomas Webster was unable to complain about her plagiarism.He had died aged  in December . He was a man ahead of his time, so got neither the payment nor recognition that he deserved but his writing, though uncredited, has stood on more bookshelves than all other Orcadian writers put together.Mrs Beeton‚Äôs Cookbook sold two million copies in its first decade alone.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney to go into level one from monday
story: breaking newsOrkney drops to Level One from MondayMay ,  at : pm vw, px"  Orkney is set to move down into Level One coronavirus restrictions from next Monday, May .First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the news this afternoon, in a COVID- briefing.Orkney is therefore skipping Level Two, due to what Ms Sturgeon called a #very low levels# of cases and #very good vaccination coverage.#In the briefing this afternoon, Ms Sturgeon said: #In our island communities the situation is dferent, and very much more positive.#Case numbers have been consistently at very low levels indeed for some time now.#Many islands also now have very good vaccination coverage.#So for those reasons, we#ve decided it is now possible and proportionate to now ease restrictions on the islands more quickly.#This will not affect travel to and from the Scottish mainland, as the government guidnace on Level One states: #you can travel anywhere in Scotland in Levels Zero, One, or Two, but must not enter a Level Three or Four area unless for a permitted reason.#Ms Sturgeon also announced thatfolk are meeting friends and family indoors or in a garden , physical distancing will no longer be required, meaning that hugging loved ones is finally permitted once more.Also dropping to Level One are the Western Islands, Shetland, all islands in the Highlands except Skye, and Inner Hebrides such as Argyle, Jura and Mull.The rest of Scotland is to drop to Level Two from the same date, excluding Moray which is to remain in Level Three due to a rise in COVID- cases.Orkney, yet again, is now ahead of the rest of mainland Scotland in terms of restrictions.Mainland Scotland is expected to enter Level One on June , and Level Zero on June . It has not been confirmed whether Orkney will continue to ease at a faster rate than the rest of the country.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney vote ignored in lockdown easing consultation
story: The results of a Scottish Government survey, designed to contribute to a decision over Orkney‚Äôs lockdown exit plan revealed a clear majority vote # but not for the option the government implemented, it has emerged.The Orcadian can exclusively reveal that two months ago, Orkney respondents overwhelmingly voted for the county to drop to a lower level of COVID- restrictions, and to forego travel to the Scottish mainland.Instead, the less favoured optionwas implemented by the government.The Scottish Government remained tight lipped over the local consultations, which ran for only two days during March, but a freedom of informationrequest submitted by The Orcadian has finally shown the numbers involved this evening.The FOI revealed that  per cent of Orkney responders voted to drop into lower restrictions, and against Lockstep. title: stromness home to feature in tv competition
story: A Stromness writer has opened the doors to her -year-old home, and allowed the nation to take a peek inside, as part of a television competition seeking to uncover Scotland#s top home.Jo Ramsey has lived at  Ness Road, part of Double House, for  years, but tonight, she will display her home in a fashion like none other.Scotland#s Home of the Year sets out to showcase outstanding homes, and sees three property experts travel to nine regions before the grand finale is held.The Orkney and Shetland episode will air on BBC Scotland tonight at pm.The judges, interior designer Anna Campbell Jones, architect Michael Angus and blogger Kate Spiers, judge the homes on three key criteria ‚Äî design, style and architecture.Jo says the unique nature of her home convinced her to agree to a friend‚Äôs suggestion that she enter it in Scotland‚Äôs Home of the Year.It marks the second consecutive year that there will be Stromness interest in the competition, after The Wheelhouse, owned by Liam Temple and Caro Stockan, was narrowly beaten in the final in .Jo, who composes poetry and short stories, and is also a copy editor, says she loved seeing Stromness being represented during last year‚Äôs programme and, while she was hesitant at first, she enjoyed the experience of allowing a film crew into her loved home.Built around , Double House is a category B-listed terraced house, and is a row of three houses back-to-back with another three at the south end of the town.‚ÄúIt has been an interesting experience,slightly nerve-wracking process,‚Äù Jo said ahead of the episode‚Äôs airing.Home since moving to Orkney from London in , Jo said she agreed to enter the competition because ‚Äúit would actually be nice to have a traditional stone Orkney house in the programme.‚ÄùThe house is up against two other homes in Shetland, with the winner going through to the national final.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: lifeboat mission leaves portree crew member in a
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineRNLI volunteers have been sharing some of the stranger situations they have found themselves in when their pagers go off to herald the lesaving charity‚Äôs Mayday Mile appeal.Iain Beaton, a member of Portree leboat, was enjoying that post-lockdown highlight, a trip to the hairdresser, when his pager sounded one day last summer.Iain, a builder who has  years‚Äô leboat service in two separate stints, said: ‚ÄúI hadn‚Äôt had a haircut in months and I was desperately looking forward to it. I had not long sat down in the salon in Portree and was getting my hair washed when my pager went off.‚ÄúI just sprinted out the door with the cape still on and my head full of shampoo ‚Äì you don‚Äôt think when you get a shout, you just go. Morven the hairdresser didn‚Äôt know what had happened and I certainly got a lot of funny looks running down the pier!‚ÄúWe went to the aid of two women who had got cut off by the tide at the back of Raasay, and they kept looking at me. Needless to say I got endless ribbing from the crew. I‚Äôm just glad Morven hadn‚Äôt started cutting or I would have looked even stranger. Morven came up to the house the next day so I did eventually get that haircut.‚ÄùThe RNLI is preparing for a busy summer with more families than ever expected to opt for holidays in the UK because of the pandemic. Many of them will be heading to the coast.To keep lesavers kitted out and trained it has launched the Mayday Mile which encourages folk to cover a one-mile distance, be it walking, running, swimming, skating or cycling, to help raise funds. and find out how to make a donation or hold a socially-distanced sponsored event.

title: editorial kennedy commitment would be a fitting cause for political
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineIt was his seventh in a row as a Highland member of parliament and with a majority of more than , in Ross, Skye and Lochaber it seemed then that his seat was secure for as long as he wanted it.Yeta week is a long time in politics, the last decade has proved aeonic.The General Election of May  brought an end to the UK‚Äôs  years of centre-left dominance, and it was to prove the first in a series of seismic polls which tore up the psephologist‚Äôs rule book.The  election gave the Liberal Democrats a taste of power in an unlikely coalition with the Tories, but it has been electoral oblivion for them ever since ‚Äì including in their former Highland heartlands.A year later the SNP romped to a majority in a Scottish parliament that had been designed to prevent any one party having overall control. In so doing the path was paved toward an independence referendum which eventually maintained the -year-old Union, but still served to elevate the question to become the defining Scottish issue of our times.‚Äì was Charles Kennedy‚Äôs.A few weeks later the affable Abrach was dead, aged just .The turbulent, and increasingly polarised times continued as a Brexit referendum was granted, and the UK ‚Äì in spite of all major parties backing remain ‚Äì voted to leave the EU in . There followed four years of painful negotiation Theresa May was anointed, became a lame duck, and departed as PM to be replaced by Boris Johnson.Johnson saw off Jeremy Corbyn and ‚Äògot Brexit done‚Äô as he said he would, but post-Covid he might yet be done for himself. As rumours rage that in preference to lockdown he said he would tolerate a virus # from which he almost died # spreading so severely that bodies could ‚Äúpile high on the streets‚Äù, there is a growing sense that the public reckoning he has long escaped may finally be in sight.Meanwhile in Scotland, having survived the ugly fall-out from of an investigation into the handling of sexual harassment complaints against her predecessor and political mentor Alex Salmond, Nicola Sturgeon remains odds-on to become First Minister again in  # perhaps even with the overall majority she was unable to secure in .Whether victory leads to a second referendum depends not only on next week‚Äôs result but on whose ‚Äòrights‚Äô will take precedence in the eyes of the UK government who by law would need to sanction another vote.Because inescapably it is Covid-, how it is tackled and treated, and how we can recover as a country from it, that is the major issue facing all of us.It seems lamentable that, amid the constitutional flux and an increasing entrenchment of views, that there has been so little sign of a consensual approach ‚Äì between both governments and parties # to steer the country away from the crisis.And that brings us back to the original point about the late Charles Kennedy.The landscape which he occupied has altered beyond recognition, but has changed politics meant better politics or brought improved outcomes  The jury is out, and it is a question voters should consider as they head for the booths.‚Äô brought some encouraging news.Having seen the treatment Mr Kennedy received back in , the LibDems have called for a ‚Äúa zero-tolerance approach to abuse and to lead a respectful campaign‚Äù.Their pledge calls for derogatory, untrue, or hateful messages on social media to be publicly denounced and challenged to treat political opponents and journalists with respect, and to run an honest campaign.The SNP, Tories, Labour and Greens ‚Äì all of whom have members who have experienced threats and abuse in ious forms ‚Äì have all signed up.It would be a fitting tribute to Charles Kennedythis is one electoral promise they can work together and fulfil.

The programme is run by the UK‚Äôs four mobile network operators and the UK Government to extend G coverage to % of the UK‚Äôs geography by the middle of this decade.Jane Wood, BT Group Scotland director, said: ‚ÄúExtending the network will offer a much-needed leline to families and businesses impacted by the ongoing pandemic, as many are working from home and keeping in touch with family and friends via digital technology.‚ÄùMartyn Cheyne, WHP strategic development director, said: ‚ÄúWHP Telecoms is pleased to have facilitated this reliable coverage by providing robust, future-proofed infrastructure from which EE is now delivering G coverage. title: barra service superhub hundreds sign
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoinePublished on Monday, the petition has already gathered well over  signatures and was created by -year-old engine cadet Eoghan MacLeod from Vatersay.: ‚ÄúI started the petition to get a measure of how many people agreed with me that the hub plan as it stands needs big changes for it to meet the needs of the island.‚ÄúI‚Äôd heard plenty of people in person talking about their concerns so I just put together what I‚Äôd heard and put it on the petition to seewe could make these concerns more visible.‚ÄúMy grandmother is currently in the old folks home at St Brendan‚Äôs as she has dementia and needs to be looked after around the clock. title: uig beach clean volunteers remove two years worth of
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineCommunity members came out in force across the course of the day with their efforts culminating in a skip-load of rubbish being cleared from Uig beach.Young and old beach buddies worked hard to remove two years‚Äô worth of waste which had accumulated since the last event in .shortly after the beach clean, Ross Watson, the north Scotland site manager for Woodland Trust Scotland said: ‚ÄúIt was gloriously warm and we must have had around  people take part in the clean over the course of today.‚ÄúIt was also a great occasion for people to catch up, so there was probably as much chatting as there was litter picking.‚ÄúWe filled the whole skip and had to work really hard to fit everything in. There was a huge amount of rope and all sorts of litter.‚ÄúBeyond that there was general litter such as Coke bottles, beer cans, and a few face masks. The only odd thing we found was a massive oxygen tank.‚ÄùHighlighting the volume of rubbish encountered during the clean, he added: ‚ÄúNearly everyone who came along was from the community and they had seen this litter building up over the last two years.‚ÄúThe beach clean is an annual event we tend to do in April but we had to cancel last year‚Äôs so this year is basically two years‚Äô worth including two winter storms‚Äô worth.‚ÄùWhen asked how much of the responsibility for the mess he believed lay with local people, he went on to say: ‚ÄúSome of the litter will certainly be from local industry but so much of it will be dropped from people on the island ‚Äì whether locally or swept in.‚ÄúThe problem is not just local to here, it‚Äôs a UK-wide issue.‚ÄùAddressing the challenges facing the village more broadly, Mr Watson said: ‚ÄúOn Friday one of our contractors pulled up two trailers of fly-tipped metal down the side of one of the bridges away from the beach.‚ÄúThat has been years‚Äô worth of local people dumping bikes, climbing frames and all sorts of bits and pieces. Both the Woodland Trust and the Uig Community Trust were speaking today about how we can make a bigger impact through this event, and how we can cover the whole of the community.‚ÄúThere is real potential for the event to be an Uig clean as a whole and not just a beach clean.‚ÄúA lot of people were saying that it was the first event that they had been to in well over a year, while some of the older people hadn‚Äôt seen anyone for months.‚ÄúIt was a real feel-good event from that side of things.‚ÄúThere was a mixture of working-age parents through to retired folks.‚ÄúIt was great to see the kids there and have a chat with their parents. The children were appalled at the amount of litter on the beach, and we were talking about what they can do to help. Getting the message across to them about these matters at an early stage is ideal.‚Äù

title: new skye homes to be sold at a fixed
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na Daoine revealed proposals by London-based developer Charlie Garton Jones to build  family homes in Portree on the site of the old golf course off the Struan Road.The plans,approved, will comprise  three-bedroom houses, and five four-bedroom houses, each with a garden and drive, situated on a site of around five acres in total.Mr Garton Jones lodged a planning application with Highland Council in late April this year, and hopes to provide homeowners with an ultrafast one gigabyte broadband connection free of charge for the first five years via the excess capacity the Bracken Hide Hotel will have from the nearby BT exchange.If given the green light, the scheme will be built on land next to where the developer is constructing his -cabin hotel, which is scheduled to open in April .Mr Garton Jones runs an independent estate agency specialising in the sale and rental of residential property in London, which has offices in Westminster, Nine Elms, Cha and Battersea.He also owns the Cow Shed boutique bunkhouse in Uig. report on Mr Garton Jones‚Äô proposals has sparked a heated debate via the paper‚Äôs Facebook page over the last few days, attracting more than  comments.Although opinions dfered on the appearance of the houses, the main point of contention centred on whether the homes would be affordable and accessible to local people.Peter Brown commented: ‚ÄúThe local community should have the final say. Personally I would think social housing should be a priority.‚ÄùWhile Helen Grianan said: ‚ÄúWill these houses be ¬£, or under  If not, they are not affordable housing for locals or key workers.‚ÄùCalum J Morrison from North Uist was in favour of the scheme saying: ‚ÄúSounds like a good type of thing in my opinion, the dude seems to know what he‚Äôs doing, good luck to him I say!‚ÄùAnnie B Campbell, meanwhile, highlighted broader issues with housing on the island, stating: ‚ÄúKey workers, like some NHS and teachers, are being outbid for most of the houses that come on the market in Skye.‚ÄúThey are not ‚Äòofficially‚Äô homeless so do not have enough points to qualy for council housing.‚ÄúSome are forced to skip between illegal short term lets. This is not simply a locals versus incomers issue.‚ÄúKey workers coming to fill essential jobs on the island and local families need somewhere to live. There is a very real housing crisis.‚ÄùMr Garton Jones said the price of the houses could not be confirmed until planning permission was obtained.However, in the last few days, he took to social media to try to address worries that people on the island will be priced-out of buying the properties.‚ÄúThere has been a lot of focus on the larger family house we are hoping to build but  of the  houses we are building are smaller, three bedroom, houses,‚Äù he commented.Kevin McMahon simply asked: ‚ÄúWill there be a first refusal for locals and the children of local families ‚ÄùIn response, Mr Garton Jones said: ‚ÄúI am happy to confirm that the properties will not be sold via the Scottish ‚Äòsealed bids offers over‚Äô system but will be sold at a fixed price on a first-come, first-served basis.‚ÄúObviously until we have planning, we cannot sell the houses, but we have opened up a ‚Äòwaiting list‚Äô., which is the only place the houses have so far been mentioned or advertised ‚Äì have emailed me to express their interest in the houses.‚ÄúMany of them do, indeed, appear to be locals, although we will not be checking birth certicates as part of the sales process.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúThere are  houses in total, soyou would like your name added to the list, please email me via charlie@gartonjonesChisolm talked about his own chances of finding a home, questioned the effectiveness of the Highland Council in its current form, and underlined the importance of investing in smaller communities on the island.‚ÄúI am living with my parents, and with my work I am fortunate to still live on Skye,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúSaying that, I haven‚Äôt taken any steps to purchase a home as the prices do not justy the property, or are just too expensive.‚ÄúI know people who have taken steps to purchase but were outbid either at the start or last minute.‚ÄùChisolm has worked for CalMac since  and says he has thought about moving to the Western Isles due to his poor prospects of finding a home on Skye.He said: ‚ÄúI have strong family connections to Lewis and Harris, and I might have the possibility of moving across as house prices haven‚Äôt been affected as much as on Skye in terms of second homes and holiday homes. However, it is now on the rise as on other neighbouring islands.‚ÄùChisolm believes a revamp of the local authority is needed to force meaningful change.‚ÄúSkye is facing issues linked to the lack of investment and communications. That makes me question why are we governed by people in Inverness and not the people of Skye and the surrounding islands.‚ÄúI look at the Western Isles, and I‚Äôm seeing housing developments across the islands in dferent areas with the goal of helping local people stay where they are from, sustaining school numbers ‚Äî including Gaelic communities ‚Äî and helping small areas grow.‚ÄúThat should be critical here and not just developing in Portree. Roads, housing, harbour investments are just a few aspects that link together and time is critical.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important for young people and young families to stay on the island with the support of affordable housing, whether that‚Äôs purchasing or renting.‚ÄùChisolm said he had been encouraged by responses to Iomairt an Eilein‚Äôs call to action.‚ÄúPolitical responses ahead of the election have been very welcoming and we are grateful for the support,‚Äù he added. reported on plans to build a new -home private scheme on the outskirts of Portree.Commenting on the merits of the proposal, Chisolm said: ‚ÄúI welcome the new development in Portree, I‚Äôm sure many young people and families from Skye will benefit from thesethey are available at an affordable price.‚ÄúThat being said, I do question why we‚Äôre only developing in Portree. I can name many schools in surrounding communities that would benefit from even a half of a development like this.‚ÄùPainting a stark picture of the dficulties facing townships such as Staffin, he said: ‚ÄúSmaller communities are missing out and our school numbers and Gaelic communities are suffering. This should be a wake-up call to our government and ‚Äòour‚Äô council that more housing investments in rural areas will have more of an impact and better outcomes.‚ÄúWe all have a right to articulate our viewpoints and opinions. Not everyone will agree but that‚Äôs what makes a community ‚Äì having dferent voices for the benefit of our island.‚Äù

title: beth backs foster fortnight with her deeds and words
story: BALLYMENA Councillor Beth Adger can speak with some authority on the topic of fostering.Having fostered nearly  youngsters over two decades, she was the ideal person to voice Mid and East Antrim Council‚Äôs support for Foster Care Fortnight. Foster Care Fortnight runs from  ‚Äì  May and aims to help and encourage the wider society to understand and value fostering and the positive dference it can make to young people‚Äôs lives.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor, Peter Johnston said: ‚ÄúThousands of new foster families are needed every year to care for children, with the greatest need being for older children, sibling groups and children with additional needs.‚ÄúCurrently, around , children and young people are living in foster care and with less people coming forward to offer homes, there has never been a greater need for foster carers. ‚ÄúYou really could make a dference to the lives of vulnerable children and young people.‚ÄùCouncillor Adger MBE shared her personal story at last week‚Äôs meeting of full council, putting forward a Notice of Motion on the issue which was unanimously supported by Elected Members.She said afterwards: ‚ÄúFoster carers in Northern Ireland do an incredible job ensuring children are nurtured, loved and protected.‚ÄúAs a foster carer myself for over  years and having fostered  children during this time, I can hand on my heart say it is the most rewarding job.‚ÄúFrom newborn to  years of age, the children that entered our home gave us so much love and it really was a pleasure to provide each child with a loving and safe environment during their time of need.‚ÄúWe hope that the increased awareness of Foster Care Fortnight will build support for fostering, challenge stigma surrounding children in foster care and encourage more people to come forward to foster. There is a good support network out there for foster carers to avail of, so you are not alone in this role.‚ÄùFor more information on Adoption or Foster Care please contact HSC Northern Ireland Adoption and Foster Care on T:    or visit W: www.adoptionandfostercare.hscn.net

title: brave jessica is an inspiration
story: JESSICA Philpott‚Äôs battle back from le changing surgery would put many an adult to shame!This is the view of proud mum Julie who told the  this week that her -year-old daughter has coped remarkably well.‚ÄúEvery day Julie has pushed on with courage, resilience and sheer determination that would put any adult to shame,‚Äù said Julie.It was back on April  that Jessica, who was born with Apert Syndrome, a Craniofacial condition that affects the development of the head and limbs, was operated on for  hours by a team of  highly skilled surgeons, ranging from neurosurgeons to craniofacial surgeons to plastic surgeons, each playing a vital role in the reshaping of Jessicas face and skull.This surgery carries high risks, risks that they were all too aware of due to the fact that surgeons were operating so close to the brain.Julie explained that distraction of Jessica‚Äôs face started on Tuesday, May , and the plan is to continue with this twice a day for - weeks.‚ÄúWe are already seeing a massive dference to the structure of Jessicas face and she is loving the change and has shown such grace and dignity throughout the last  weeks, we are immensely proud of her,‚Äù said JulieNo chat with Julie or Jessica is complete with a mention of the Slemish College pupil‚Äôs beloved Ballymena United!‚ÄúThe love and support for Jessica from everyone at the club over the last few years has been amazing, but in particular over the last few weeks theyve been there willing her on,‚Äù outlined Julie.Meanwhile, the surgery that Jessica has just had is actually one of,not the most expensive surgeries in the world!‚ÄúGreat Ormond Street Hospital has fully funded this surgery for Jessica and we cannot thank them enough for what theyve done for Jessica and I during our stay here so far,‚Äù said Julie.‚ÄúNot just the surgeons, nurses and medical team, but also the auxillary staff, domestic staff and catering staff, they all play a vital role and have been a tremendous source of support and encouragement to us as a family. It truly is a wonderful place and there is nowhere  Id rather be at this stage of Jessicas Journey.‚ÄùJessica also asked her mum to share pictures of her with her frame on, saying it will give people the chance to see what she looks like now.Mum Julie recalls the day of surgery, describing it a ‚Äúbit of a blur‚Äù for her.‚ÄúThe Team came to the Ward to see me. Professor Dunaway, the lead surgeon, was smiling, they all were. He said they were finished and all went exceptionally well. I sobbed, happy tears, tears of sheer relief that it was over. He went on to say that there had been absolutely no complications. In fact Jessica had sailed through the surgery. She hadnt even needed a blood transfusion which is almost always a given with this type of surgery. The team advised that it would be another two hours before Jessica would be in recovery.‚ÄùJulie said those last two hours ‚Äúwere definitely the longest of the day.‚Äù‚ÄúAround pm the nurse took me to recovery, nothing could have prepared me for what I was about to see. Jessica bruised, swollen and had wires, tubes and drains everywhere. But there in the middle of it all her little voice said Mummy can I have something to eat,‚Äù recalled Julie.Mum explained that over the next seven days they had ‚Äúgood days and not so good days.‚Äù‚ÄúBut the staff on the High Dependency Ward were nothing short of amazing. They looked after me as much as they looked after Jessica. They actually made us feel like we were the only family on the ward, They are very special people who go above and beyond every day for families like ours.‚ÄùJessica has amazed staff, surgeons and family with her recovery.On Day  Professor Dunaway told Julie in his entire career he has never seen a recovery like it, describing it as ‚Äúamazing.‚Äù‚ÄúI replied Our God is amazing, it really has been nothing short of a miracle,‚Äù said Julie.As the week progressed the Surgical Team gradually informed Julie of what they had done in theatre.They explained that because Jessica was coping so well under the anaesthetic, they decided to do a little bit extra to ensure that Jessica had the best possible outcome from the surgery.‚ÄúThey didnt just fit the frame as planned, they bone grafted her a new nose, they gave her a cheek lt and plated her forehead. So, in light of all of this it made her recovery even more of a miracle,‚Äù smiled Julie‚ÄúIt also re-iterated to me that these surgeons are very special people, who go above and beyond on a daily basis for children like Jessica. They want the very best for them and they will do everything in their power to improve their quality of le. Thank you just doesnt go far enough, we will be eternally grateful to that Team.‚ÄùHusband Lawrie was able to join Jessica and Julie for the weekend - ‚Äúto help us with the move‚Äù, quipped Julie.‚ÄúWe‚Äôve managed to accumulate quite a bit of ‚Äòstuff‚Äô over the last seven days, but it was horrible having to say goodbye.‚ÄùJulie reports that Jessica has started to eat and drink more orally so not requiring as many tube feeds, swelling is going down gradually and continuing to improve daily!Regarding her frame, the screws will be turned twice a day for the next few weeks, gradually changing the shape of Jessica‚Äôs face.Mum Julie is always very mindful to thank all those who have sent texts, cards gts and prayed for them.‚ÄúIt has been absolutely amazing and were so thankful to have the first week done with no major complications. As someone said to me ‚Äòfirst week done , a road never to be traveled again‚Äô.‚ÄúIt was tough, there were tears . There were good days, there were not so good days but we‚Äôve done it and know that God was with us and will continue to be with us in the days and weeks ahead,‚Äù said Julie.And Julie makes no secret of the fact that faith has got her through this very challenging time.‚ÄúObviously our faith has been a major factor in how we, as a family, have been able to cope with all of this. And the outpouring of prayer, practical and emotional support from our own church, Ballyloughan Presbyterian, Connor Presbyterian where Jessica attends GB and Youth Club and Woodlands Presbyterian in Carrick who have adopted us, along with many other churches and iniduals from every denomination has been special. And we would like to thank everyone whos been praying and offering practical support, it has meant so much to us and it has been wonderful to see so many people being the church.‚ÄùJulie said they had every faith in the Surgical Team, and ‚Äúand more importantly we knew that Jessica and that team were covered in prayer leading up to and for the duration of the surgery. Churches of all denominations, iniduals and groups of people from all faiths had prayer rotas going throughout the day, and so we had a peace about this surgery from the outset.‚ÄùIndeed, a verse of scripture that was very poignant in the week leading up to this surgery was Isaiah : -  So do not fear, for I am with you, do not be dismayed, for I am your God, I will strengthen you and help you, I will uphold you with my righteous right hand.‚ÄúThis verse was in my head as I walked out of the anaesthetic room that morning, it was the most dficult thing I have ever had to do. But I knew that God was in complete control and would carry Jessica, the team and me through that day and in the days to come,‚Äùsaid Julie.The Jessicas Journey Facebook and Instagram pages have been a real source of encouragement to them as a family over the last couple of weeks.‚ÄúWe currently have .K followers and so I think we have achieved our aim of raising awareness of Craniofacial conditions. The comments, well wishes, prayers and support of thousands of people on the page have carried us through the dark days - thank you to each and every person whos taken the time to comment or message, you really have made a dference and you have restored our faith in humanity,‚Äù concluded Julie.

AMFacebookTwitterEmailAlmost ¬£bn of public money was spent or has been set aside for Covid support schemes by Stormont departments without being signed off by the relevant permanent secretary, it has emerged.One MLA said a review and evaluation of the schemes will be important in the time ahead.Due to the need to spend vast amounts of money within a short timeframe, around a third of the total ¬£bn in Covid spending here was pushed through via ministerial directions throughout the pandemic.This means the funds were approved directly by ministers when permanent secretaries raised issues such as inability to assess value for money ‚Äî so they could not sign off on them.Figures obtained by the Belfastshow that a total of ¬£.m has been¬†spent in this way throughout the pandemic.Two of the most expensive schemes signed off via ministerial direction were the Department of Finance#s extension of financial support for the Derry City and Strabane district, which cost ¬£.m.The other was the Department for the Economy#s business support grant scheme, costing ¬£m.Other schemes included¬†the ¬£k Covid business support grant for the retail, hospitality, tourism and leisure sectors, which cost ¬£m, and the Covid micro-business hardship scheme, which ¬£m went towards.Some schemes are currently still progressing and have not been paid out yet, such as the ¬£ bonus for health and social care staff, for which ¬£m has been set aside.Alliance MLA Andrew Muir said the devastating nature of the Covid pandemic has required an unprecedented response in terms of both size and speed to support people, businesses and those on the front line.He said this has inevitably required formal directions being issued by ministers to civil servants to hand out funds, something previously rightly considered both unusual and meriting thorough examination.These should not become a regular feature of public spending. With permanent secretaries often raising concerns about value for money and the inability to properly mitigate the risks associated with potential misuse of public funds, review and evaluation of the schemes approved under ministerial direction will be important in the time ahead, he said.We should however also recognise that the original aims to get help to those in need was laudable and hindsight is a wonderful thing. An immense effort was put in by civil servants to deliver the support needed with some working long hours, seven days a weeks for which I remain truly grateful.We may all judge things dferently in the cold light of day when the immense pressure to turn around support has dissipated but reviewing lessons learnt will be crucial alongside why schemes where estimated to cost much more than what was paid out with strict eligibility criteria and application processes often deterring precisely those the initiatives were designed to assist.The Department of Financesaid: ‚ÄúWhen an inidual minister confirms a direction to their accounting officer, either the DoF minister‚Äôs approval is sought or a decision is reached at the Executive to agree to the course of action.The accounting officer will then noty the Comptroller and Auditor General who will in turn alert the Public Accounts Committee.‚ÄúThe issuing of ministerial directions has enabled much needed financial assistance to be delivered to support the health service, help businesses, safeguard jobs and protect the most vulnerable in society.‚ÄùWith unprecedented levels of Government spending due to the pandemic, many have predicted a severe economic downturn ‚Äî¬†and even a recession ‚Äî in the near future, when some funds need to be repaid.Last month, the Executive agreed funding for a ¬£m plan to help the economy recover from the impact of the Covid- pandemic.Finance Minister Conor Murphy, however, warned that, when one-off Covid funding is excluded, most departments will see their core budget fall in real terms.Choices will have to be made, public services will have to be prioritised,‚Äù he said.Covid has presented massive challenges but the vaccination programme has been hugely successful and we hope we can soon move towards economic recovery.Earlier this month the Belfastreported¬†the potential need to top-slice departmental budgets by more than ¬£.bn over the next two decades to fund the pension scheme for those injured during the Troubles,the Treasury does not foot the bill. title: bbc accused of edwin poots lambast over religious beliefs
story: Newly-selected DUP leader Edwin Poots. Photo: Press EyeKelvin Boyes   Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNewly-selected DUP leader Edwin Poots. Photo: Press EyeEimear McGovernTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailDUP MP Ian Paisley Jr has accused the BBC of ‚Äúlambasting‚Äù the incoming leader of the DUP Edwin Poots over his religious beliefs in a tense exchange on the Newsnight programme.The North Antrim MP said the broadcaster had ‚Äútaken the mickey out of‚Äù Edwin Poots after the selection of the Minister for Agriculture to replace Arlene Foster as leader of the DUP - but a spokesperson for the BBC denied this had been the case.‚ÄúThe BBC want to lambast the man because he happens to be a man of faith and they want to take the mickey out of his religion, you wouldn‚Äôt do thathe was a Muslim. You should be ashamed of yourselves and the BBC should be ashamed of yourselves for starting from that position,‚Äù he said.¬†Read MoreEdwin Poots set to pressure Arlene Foster to quit First Minister post earlySuzanne Breen:OpinionEdwin Poots‚Äô honeymoon won‚Äôt last long¬†Mr Poots, a Free Presbyterian, is ‚Äúentitled to be the leader and he‚Äôs entitled to have his faith‚Äù, said Mr Paisley.‚ÄúHe has never been in a position where he would try and force his faith down your throat or anyone ‚Äôs throat and he would not allow those things get in the way of how he engages in policy and policy-making.‚ÄùA spokesperson from the BBC said on Saturday: ‚ÄúAt no point did anyone on the programme mock religious beliefs.‚ÄùMr Paisley said as DUP leader, Mr Poots interest is ‚Äúmaking Northern Ireland work‚Äù.‚ÄúHe has an excellent track record of working with Sinn Fein [and] other people across the board to make this place a better place.‚ÄùMr Poots will be an ‚Äúauthentic voice‚Äù for a community which currently feels ‚Äúyou‚Äôre not allowed to have an opinion that might offend someone in some other quarter, that opinion can now be voiced‚Äù, Mr Paisley added.‚ÄúI‚Äôm reminded of the Frank Skinner line, you can be anything in Britain today except a Christian.‚ÄùAfter Arlene Foster was recently overthrown by the party, Mr Pootswas named her successor on Friday after a successful leadership campaign in which his only rival was MP Sir Jeffrey Donaldson.Mr Paisley, a supporter of Mr Poots, said his leadership of the party will be focused on several key issues, one of which is the Northern Ireland Protocol which he pledged to ‚Äúfight‚Äù. Mr Paisley said on Friday night the protocol could be ‚Äúfixed‚Äù.‚ÄúThe protocol with regards to business in Northern ireland is destroying business, whether you‚Äôre a Catholic businessman, a Protestant businessman a businessman or woman from any other tradition, it‚Äôs destroying business, lets try and fix it,‚Äù he said.A meeting has taken place with the Secretary of State Brandon Lewis to address the issue, he added. ‚ÄúEvery single unionist in this country is opposed to it, it is not sustainable.‚ÄúWithin Article  there‚Äôs a lawful way of changing it, [it] allows us to ensure those elements that affect the society, the economy, which create destabilisation, those elements can be fixed and changed. seat of the SDLP‚Äôs Mark Durkan in Donna DeeneyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFor a party that likes to keep its internal business out of the spotlight, the recent headlines around Sinn Fein‚Äôs troubles in Londonderry have been deeply unwelcome.It is just four years since their greatest day in the city ‚Äî when Elisha McCallion became MP for Foyle, storming what had been a citadel of power for the SDLP.Today, Foyle is back in the hands of the SDLP ‚Äî ed by a landslide at the  general election ‚Äî and Sinn Fein‚Äôs north west operation lies in tatters.The party‚Äôs two Foyle MLAs, Martina Anderson and Karen Mullan, have been publicly humiliated by the national leadership who unceremoniously told them they should resign their seats in Stormont.One of Sinn Fein‚Äôs most high-profile figures, Ms Anderson has represented the party as an MLA, junior minister and MEP since . She was co-opted back as MLA for Foyle in March . Ms Mullan replaced Ms McCallion as a Foyle MLA in June .Gone too are a number of key figures who were at the helm of the party in Derry for decades.Sinn Fein have said this ‚Äúreview‚Äù is so they can rebuild the party after two disastrous elections ‚Äî the  Foyle loss followed a poor showing in the council elections in Derry earlier that year.But people close to the party in the city say that change was long overdue and the reasons for the review were more complicated than simply whose name might be on the ballot paper.The Belfastspoke to a range of well placed sources close to the party in Derry. Most did not want to be named but all concurred with the outcome of the review and the need for it.One source said: ‚ÄúBad election results can be down to bad messages or bad mechanics but this is deeper than that.‚ÄúThere have been major issues within the party for a number of years and I don‚Äôt believe they centre around elections. The governance of the party has been a big issue, there were a series of really bad decisions.‚ÄùThey added: ‚ÄúThese issues have been allowed to grow and fester and I am glad the national leadership have reacted in the way they have.‚ÄùA second source added: ‚ÄúIt is clear that the status of the party in Derry has plummeted in recent years and that is seen by the turnout at local government and Westminster elections in .‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the party had much of a choice other than to investigate why its political fortunes have been damaged.‚ÄúI do know what they found was not a pretty picture and it was decided that the current party structure and personnel in the city were not suited to a period of revitalisation and rebuilding, including the two co-opted political representatives in Stormont.‚ÄùWhile results suggested the performance and perception of the two elected representatives seemed less than inspiring to the electorate, it was the less public faces around the table that rankled voters.Our source explained: ‚ÄúHow the party has been organised and what rules it abided by has been open to speculation and ridicule for many years.‚ÄùThey said selection issue have played a part in the decrease of the solid working class vote the party has traditionally got in places like Creggan. Bogside, Shantallow, Ballymagroarty and the Waterside.The source added: ‚ÄúThe votes in all of those areas were dramatically down. Losing five seats in the  local government elections was a big, big deal.‚ÄùSinn Fein‚Äôs power was never stronger in Derry than it was in  ‚Äî the year Martin McGuinness passed away ‚Äî but had he still been alive, those close to the party think the outcome of this review would have been the same.‚ÄúI think Martin would have been a bit more diplomatic in his approach, particularly towards Martina,‚Äù one source observed.‚ÄúPeople use their own style of party management but at the end of the day, the choices were still stark and the conclusions that the party has come to were inescapable.‚ÄúIt has all crystallised because of the election results and the Elisha McCallion debacle is seen as the final nail in the coffin.‚ÄùMs McCallion‚Äôs election as MP for Foyle in  was undoubtedly a pivotal moment for Sinn Fein in Derry and came two years after Derry City Council merged with Strabane District Council and Sinn Fein became the majority party.Seen by some as one of the party‚Äôs bright new names, just days after her election as MP, Ms McCallion posted pictures of the hotel room in Westminster borough, complaining about how small it was. It didn‚Äôt sit well with many grassroots Sinn Fein voters, and that it came a day after  people lost their lives in the nearby Grenfell fire that left hundreds of other homeless was even worse.Her crass comment did little to endear her to the electorate.Nor did a quip she made during the  election campaign to people living in a socially deprived area of Derry, where she would have expected votes, about how they could open their doors because she ‚Äúwas not the debt collector‚Äù.This cost Ms McCallion her Westminster seat but lessons were not learned and just weeks after her election to the Seanad in , it emerged she failed toimmediately a Covid payment of ¬£, mistakenly paid into her account.In politics, perception matters and this could be the reason the national leadership of Sinn Fein concluded that Martina Anderson needed to leave the stage.Ms Anderson is perceived by nationalists as someone still stuck in the past but a lot of republicans viewed her dancing antics at a Hunger Strike commemoration held in Strabane in  as ‚Äúhighly disrespectful to those who gave up their lives‚Äù.Without a doubt, the way Ms Anderson has been shoved aside will rankle with some ‚Äî the anger contained within the lines of her family‚Äôs statement at how she was treated will not have been confined to her relatives.But a source said the writing for Martina Anderson and her Stormont colleague was on the wall, adding: ‚ÄúI think republicans will have a natural sympathy and affinity with Martina because of who she is and what she had done in her le ‚Äî between her IRA and prison record and then going to represent the party in Europe.‚ÄúTo be frank, Karen Mullan will get none of that, despite being in Stormont four years, she is relatively unknown, not tested and on the grapevine, she is deemed unelectable.‚ÄúThat is why they are being asked to go. It is not any personal gripe. Karen Mullan is deemed by the party to be unelectable and Martina is past her best and that has been evident in Derry for quite a few years.‚ÄùThe next Assembly election will most likely take place in May , giving Sinn Fein just  months to turn its fortunes around.Can it be done  There are those close to the party who think so.‚ÄúThe task now is about building up confidence of people both within the city and within the party in terms of leadership. It is about reassuring people that they can have their say and that it won‚Äôt be dismissed or undermined,‚Äù another source close to the party said.‚ÄúPart of that will come down to the leadership ‚Äî the type of people who will be in charge, they will need to be trusted and liked and valued as republicans as well. The message being sent out is that it is rebuild, refocus but whether it can be delivered in  months remains to be seen.‚ÄúIdeally this should have been done two years ago and  months seems to be quite a high expectation but that doesn‚Äôt mean you don‚Äôt attempt to do it.‚ÄùKey figures within republicanism in Derry unconnected with Sinn Fein think this sweep has come too late for the party but will create opportunities for the smaller parties and independents.One said: ‚ÄúIt will be dficult for Sinn Fein to find a suitable candidate that people will get behind and vote for in time for the next Assembly election but people in Derry are fed up with them.‚ÄúYou only have to look at the last local election to see that ‚Äî Gary Donnelly topped the poll in Foyle and other independents did really well. People Before Profit won two seats, Alliance won a seat.‚ÄúI think an independent would do really well in an Assembly election, the only thing is, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any that have the inclination or the money pot Sinn Fein has to run against them.‚ÄùMs Mullan has not commented publicly since it emerged she would stand down.In a video message posted online, Ms Anderson described the review‚Äôs recommendation as a ‚Äúbody blow‚Äù and acknowledged it had been a ‚Äúdficult time‚Äù for her and Ms Mullan.She emphasised that she had been contacted by ‚Äúcomrades, friends and supporters from across Derry and beyond offering their solidarity and support‚Äù and said the ‚Äúmajority‚Äù had ‚Äúurged me to stay on‚Äù.In a Facebook post, Ms Anderson‚Äôs sister, Sharon Burke, said the family believed she had been ‚Äúsacriced‚Äù by the party.She said the party review in Londonderry ‚Äúresulted in a massive miscarriage of justice‚Äù and the way it was done was ‚Äúbrutal‚Äù.The party ‚Äúcame into Derry to fix problems and left creating more,‚Äù she said.Earlier this week, Sinn Fein vice-president Michelle O‚ÄôNeill defended the party‚Äôs decisions.‚ÄúWe believe the change we‚Äôre going to bring forward will hopefully command the confidence of the people of Foyle,‚Äù Ms O‚ÄôNeill said on Wednesday.She added: ‚ÄúBoth Martina and Karen will be part of that change, but there‚Äôs work to do in terms of building confidence.‚ÄùMs O‚ÄôNeill described Ms Anderson as a ‚Äúfirst class republican‚Äù and that she had worked with the party‚Äôs review group to shape its
