She is commonly described as outgoing, ordinary and sociable by Assembly colleagues.She is certainly the DUP‚Äôs most liberal representative on social issues. When asked about same-sex marriage by this newspaper in , she predicted that it would be legalised in the next decade due to ‚Äúchanging attitudes‚Äù.She voiced her disapproval of Gregory Campbell‚Äôs ‚Äòcurry my yoghurt‚Äô mockery of the Irish language in . Neither was she impressed when Sammy Wilson refused to wear a red ribbon in solidarity with those living with HIV AIDS.‚ÄúI#m a member of the DUP who has worked and formed really good friendships with people of dferent religions and sexual orientations,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúI know those people for who they are and that has given me a broader outlook. I can see how some of the decisions we make affect people. I see faces when I make decisions.‚Äù Although she believes in God, she is not a practising Christian.Bradley grew up in Mossley in Newtownabbey. Her mum was a social worker, her dad was a driver, and her brother Daniel is a hairdresser. She had a big extended family and summers were spent in her grandparents‚Äô caravan in Ballyhalbert.She has two adult children, Josh and Jess, with ex-husband Robert Bradley. They were orced at . ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt amicable and we‚Äôre not in touch,‚Äù she candidly admitted in a wide ranging Belfastinterview in .‚ÄúWe were too young. I was  when I got married. If one of my children had come home at  and told me they were getting married, I#d have said #No way#.‚ÄùAs a young mother, she got into debt, facing the repossession of her home after she separated from her husband. ‚ÄúHe went back to England and I was left with a mortgage and two children. Financially, it was really, really hard,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúThey were coming the following day to evict me, then I told my parents. They went to the mortgage company, took out a loan and paid what I owed. The arrears had crept up, but I#d buried my head in the sand. I ignored the problem because I didn#t want to be seen as a failure as a mother.‚ÄúIt was a traumatic period. I had two children, aged seven and five, who needed me and I was the one who was supposed to look after and protect them.‚ÄùOn leaving school, she had worked in a canteen kitchen before joining the RUC as a part-time reserve when she was . Bradley was one of the few women in the force at the time. She says it was ‚Äúan interesting job, but not the career I wanted.‚ÄùShe secured a communications job in DUP headquarters in . After that, she worked as a social care assistant for the Northern Trust from -, but she remained politically active.She was elected onto Newtownabbey Council in  and became mayor in . Nigel Dodds asked her to run for Stormont in . Her son told her to ‚Äúwise up‚Äù but she talked him round, and she was elected.Bradley told this reporter last year that she had never experienced sexism at Stormont, and that her previous jobs in the police and health service had been much more challenging in that regard.But she said social media abuse was widespread: ‚ÄúYou#re called horrendous names. I#m not just a politician, I#m a mummy and a granny.‚ÄúI#ve been told #You should have been aborted at birth# and #I hope your children die#. My kids read this stuff. When I put out a statement online, I#m fearful of what will come.Yes she said there was a spirit of sisterhood in Stormont: ‚ÄúWomen from other parties will ring each other and support each other when something horrible happens.‚ÄùShe has said she is frequently mistaken for Alliance MLA, Paula Bradshaw: ‚ÄúWe both receive each other#s mail and emails. Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandBelfast BeatUKRepublic of IrelandWorldPoliticsBrexitHealthEducationCourtsObituariesArchiveBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumIt‚Äôs the last word from Jeanie Johnston as she announces her retirementEx-UTV woman on how her le had changed over the last decadeExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFormer UTV reporter Jeanie Johnston is retiring from her job with the South Eastern Trust FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFormer UTV reporter Jeanie Johnston is retiring from her job with the South Eastern TrustClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJeanie¬†Johnston turned for one last look at the Ulster Hospital on Friday before leaving for the final time.The former UTV reporter could be forgiven for having bittersweet memories of the place.On the one hand, it is where she has spent  happy years as head of communications at the South Eastern Trust.On the other, it is where she lost her infant son Conor, who lived for just four days before succumbing to a heart defect.And the Dundonald building will also be her last place of work.‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to getting up in the morning and sitting looking out at the Mournes,‚Äù said Carrickfergus-born Jeanie, who has lived on the Ards Peninsula since the early s.‚ÄúI was intending to sell it, to downsize when I retired, but I decided I couldn‚Äôt leave it, the views were too lovely.‚ÄùA lot has changed in Jeanie‚Äôs le in the new millennium. She got orced from her husband of  years, William Hull, saw the couple‚Äôs two children Fi and Euan fly the nest, got herself a new partner and of course made a ‚Äòpoacher turned gamekeeper‚Äô switch from reporting to public relations.It is fair to say that, workwise, the last year has been the most challenging.‚ÄúI‚Äôm good in a crisis and Covid- really was a crisis it still is,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúWe had so many messages to put out. Close the hospitals to visitors, stay m apart, wear face coverings... every time something happened, we had to change the signage around the hospital and the messages on social media and where. It was mad, but I had a brilliant team.‚ÄùShe added: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been so inspired by the people who work in this Trust.‚ÄúThe other day, for instance, I overheard one nurse asking the othershe was coming for lunch and the other replied ‚ÄòNo, a patient in my ward is so worried about his dog I‚Äôve been going up every day at lunchtime to walk it‚Äô.‚ÄúHere was someone on a -hour sht giving up her only meal for a wee man who she knows won‚Äôt get well while he‚Äôs fretting about his dog.‚ÄùJeanie appeared to change careers effortlessly in  after  years in UTV, but now admits it was ‚Äúa huge transition‚Äù.‚ÄúLeaving was like missing an arm or a leg,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúUTV really was a family. I almost grieved for that family when I left.‚ÄùDeparture from the broadcaster was, however, inevitable.‚ÄúThere really didn‚Äôt seem to be a place left for me,‚Äù she recalled.‚ÄúUTV Le, the programme I edited, was axed [it has since been brought back] and my actual job role as features editor was also axed.‚ÄúTelevision was a wonderful world to work in but I‚Äôve really enjoyed my time at the Trust. The health service is full of inspirational people.‚ÄùShe is proud of her Trust being the first locally to embrace social media, which was in its infancy when she started.‚ÄúIt was a bit of an uphill struggle at the start because people still think it‚Äôs a bad thing but for us it has become an important medium, especially during the pandemic,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúThe mainstream media are only interested in the big stories but we‚Äôve been able to showcase all the other important things that go on in the Trust as well. I‚Äôm looking forward to going, but also sorry to leave.‚ÄùJeanie , who is being succeeded at the Trust by another ex-UTV reporter, Jane Loughrey, can now spend more quality time with partner Gary Mawhinney , a retired sound engineer and former UTV colleague.‚ÄúIt turned out that we‚Äôd known each other most of our lives but we only realised recently that we were very good as a couple,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúTo be honest, I didn‚Äôt expect to meet anybody . I didn‚Äôt want to for a lot of years. PMFacebookTwitterEmailNo stranger to the glare of the media spotlight, Edwin Poots ‚Äî¬†the DUP‚Äôs new leader in waiting ‚Äî could still have been forgiven for being overwhelmed after suddenly finding himself the focus of headlines in Northern Ireland and beyond,¬†but he¬†took the press attention in his stride on Friday.¬†He strolled down from Stormont buildings, statesmanlike and assured to a waiting, eager scrum of camera crews and journalists.A member of the media remarked the entire affair in the selection of the fourth DUP leader in its -year history ‚Äî the only one to stand in a leadership contest ‚Äî was akin to the Vatican choosing a pope.Earlier joggers, dog walkers and couples had been taking advantage of the hazy spring sunshine while visitors took snaps of the Stormont building.Suddenly the calm, quiet air of the Stormont estate was interrupted by an onslaught of media vans, taking up positions in the shadow of the Edward Carson statue.The political landmark is a familiar backdrop for many a press conference but there hasn‚Äôt been one with such a buzz of excitement since before the pandemic struck.As the press positioned their cameras, one visitor, taking in the panoramic view of east Belfast and beyond, gave a cautiously optimistic welcome to the news of Poots‚Äô appointment, but urged the party to now reunite.‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a good decision,‚Äù he remarked. ‚ÄúThe DUP need a refresh and I hope the new leadership will provide that.‚ÄúI‚Äôm not too sure about Poots, some of his views he‚Äôs had in the past would have split opinion.‚ÄùJust minutes later the man of the moment finally appeared: looking relaxed and carefree, and smiling for the cameras alongside newly-elected deputy leader Paula Bradley ‚Äî the first woman to be elected to the post.The Lisburn man, who not that long ago was undergoing treatment for cancer, dutully obliged when photographers, keen to get the perfect shot to capture the historic moment, ordered him to move left or right.Following a brief speech, in which he pledged to reinvigorate unionism, he was, however, less obliging when it came to answering the barrage of questions from reporters, with Ian Paisley ‚Äî one of Mr Poots‚Äô most vocal supporters during the contest ‚Äî deflecting queries.Mr Poots was then swtly whisked away in a waiting car, much to the frustration of journalists, wanting off-the-cuff answers to the big questions facing unionism. The historic parallels between the challenges facing the DUP leader designate and the forefather of unionism, Carson, who campaigned to stop Home Rule, are almost too obvious to draw attention to.And the media and the public will demand answers to them sooner than later.For now, though, Mr Poots can enjoy the buzz around his appointment.As he was ferried off, a family looked on bemused, with a child asking: ‚ÄúWill this be on TV ‚Äù The answer was yes. Photo: ReutersAndrew Madden and Gareth CrossMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailMONDAYThe week kicked off with Edwin Poots setting out his stall for the job of DUP leader, vowing to end reactionary policy making.We can no longer sustain the ad hoc approach that has been a feature of recent years, with policy on the hoof and little regard to the wishes of the elected members who have to believe in and defend the policies of the party, he wrote in his manesto.During a debate on Northern Ireland‚Äôs first climate change bill in the Assembly, former nuclear submarine captain Steve Aiken acknowledged that he would seem an unlikely candidate to be an eco-warrior.He said that, while working in the Arctic while he was in the Navy, he observed a ,-year-old sea of ice. When he ed to the area a few years later ‚Äúthat ice had gone‚Äù.Jim Allister revealed to no one#s surprise that he isn#t a fan of the bill, pointing to its potential impact on the agri-food sector.‚ÄúI am saying that the answer is not to take % of our animals and slaughter them or to take % of our production and export it to the depleting rainforests of Brazil and then sit back smugly and say, ‚ÄòDidn#t we do well # That is the ethos of the Bill, he said in the chamber.People, much as [DUP MLA Jim Wells] might not like it, will continue to buy meat. Do they buy the meat produced in north Antrim or the meat produced on land that has been stripped in the Amazon basin  That is an issue that politicians in the Western world have to consider.Ulster Unionist MLA Roy Beggs took issue with the emission targets in the bill, including a goal of zero emissions by . He said they are set over a compressed time frame and go way beyond UK Climate Change Committee targets.Green Party leader Clare Bailey, who tabled the bill, interjected. Does the member realise that his party#s manesto commits to net zero by , which is much faster and a much more compressed time frame  she said.I believe that that was a Westminster manesto, Mr Beggs replied.At a press conference addressing his resignation as UUP leader, Mr Aiken was asked which task was harder, commanding a nuclear submarine or leading the UUP. He wryly remarked: I think I#ll plead the fth on that one.TUESDAYThe climate change debate continued into Tuesday, with Jim Wells rounding on the Environment Minister, and his party colleague, Edwin Poots, over his opposition to the bill.Why are we giving planning permission for peat extraction and the development of peatlands when they have so much potential to store carbon  Why has the department not completed the area of special scientic interest, special protection area and special area of conservation designations  he said.The [conservation] Act came in in , and I am able to tell him how long ago that was because I was in the chamber when it passed. Here we are,  years later, and we still have not completed our [Areas of Special Scientic Interest] designation.Alliance#s Kellie Armstrong said: I thank the proposers of the motion it is an important debate. I will have to recommend myself for disciplinary action because I find myself agreeing with Mr Wells far too much.Oh no, replied Mr Wells.Sinn Fein#s Jemma Dolan raised a point of order later on in the chamber, saying she had secured an adjournment debate - a way of enabling the House to have a debate on a subject without considering a substantive motion - two weeks ago, but Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon released a statement on the same issue on Tuesday morning.That undermines the role of MLAs and the authority of the chamber to hold ministers to account. I ask the Speaker#s Office to look into this to see whether proper procedure and protocol were followed, she said.Speaker Alex Maskey sympathised: I say directly to the minister that, having seen that her statement was issued a number of hours ago, in advance of the adjournment debate that was scheduled for this afternoon in the order paper, I can understand why a member would feel aggrieved.It is not for me to judge why that happened, but I will write to the Executive again because I want to make sure that ministers reflect on when they issue statements, particularly on sitting days and when the minister is scheduled to come to a particular debate to make a statement.WEDNESDAYA potential sign of things to come was aired on Wednesday, when Edwin Poots no-showed a North South ministerial agriculture meeting. Nichola Mallon, the Infrastructure Minister, was also due to take part, stating it doesn#t bode wellthis is what the future holds. Powersharing requires leadership, she tweeted.It emerged Brexit minister Lord Frost and Secretary of State Brandon Lewis were in Northern Ireland on Monday meeting with the Loyalist Communities Council - but no one seemed to notice at the time.Independent MLA Trevor Lunn asked a Stormont officialshe knew Lord Frost was visiting.‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt wholly unexpected, but I wasn‚Äôt aware of the date in advance,‚Äù responded the official.Mr Lunn said: I think they must have smuggled him in and smuggled him out again.When the Assembly#s Economy Committee heard from Minister Diane Dodds on Wednesday, questions were raised around her own future.As she outlined her post-pandemic economic recovery plan Alliance MLA Stewart Dickson noted she might not be Economy Minister much longer.Edwin Poots has committed to reshuffling the DUP#s ministerial team.How do you see your successor, or a future mandate, taking forward your economy plan , Mr Dickson asked.Mrs Dodds replied: ‚ÄúWhat I do or I don#t do after this week or next week will be for the party leader and that is fine with me.THURSDAYThursday saw a meeting of the Health Committee, with members briefed on the topic of gambling addiction.Sinn Fein#s Colm Gildernew said he was ‚Äútaken aback‚Äù before the pandemic to learn that one in  suicides ‚Äúare linked to gambling addiction‚Äù.He asked an officialthere were any plans to develop services to tackle the problem, to which the official replied: There are no specic gambling addiction services.Nothing much gets past TUV leader Jim Allister. This week he received an answer to questions around why Union flags flown at Stormont to mark the birthday of Queen Elizabeth on April  were lowered before sunset. In a written response the Assembly Commission said the flags were lowered at .pm, ahead of the closure of the Assembly at pm, with restricted opening hours during the coronavirus pandemic. Previously the flags would have flown until just before pm.FRIDAYIt was a monumental day for unionism, with the DUP voting for their new leader. Outside party HQ in Belfast, Jim Wells was asked about the possibility of Sir Jeffrey Donaldson running as an MLA in his constituency in the next Assembly election.Mr Wells said Sir Jeffrey previously represented North Down and still has a lot of family there, however he is glad the Donaldsons on the electoral register voted for him the last time round.He hasn#t gone away, you know, he added.Alas, it was not be for Sir Jeffrey#s leadership ambitions, as he fell by two votes to Edwin Poots. Derry Trades Union Councilhas launched a local workers survey and has encouraged workers across the council area to complete it in order to build better workplaces. Chair of DTUC, Niall McCarroll, says that as a working class movement DTUC has provided a voice for workers and social justice campaigns. It aims to further reach out with the launch of a local workers survey, as it extends its solidarity with the people of Derry and District demanding an end to the many hardships which workers and their families experience and have experienced for far too long. Mr McCarroll says: Like everyone  I have listened to plenty of guff over the years. Hang in there is the message from all sections of the establishment, we are sympathetic and very empathetic we know things are dficult butyou keep working for nothing with no improvements things will improve. googletag.cmd.push Nurses, hotel workers, health care assistants, nursing home workers, shop workers, classroom assistants, retail workers, community, voluntary sector workers and indeed call centre staff have all heard this and still they wait, we all wait. We need to organise and begin to direct our own affairs, we need to represent ourselves because we are not being represented. He adds: Derry Trades Union Council call upon all local workers to join a trade union, get active in your local branch and shape your trade union into a fighting, working class organisation. This is how we will change our lives make our communities better, create a culture of solidarity across all workplaces, uniting all workers. Lets begin to create this new modern workers movement. googletag.cmd.push Unionised workers of the past, including our local factory workers championed the cause of labour and won many of the rights we take for granted today such as maternity pay,  hour days and weekends off. Todays demands are not being won, workers need decent pay and we must collectively mobilise to end the scourge of poverty pay, creating the situation were no worker needs to work two jobs to survive. By completing the DTUC survey we can commence the call to mobilise, use this survey to bring us together - together we can make a dference - together we can deliver for each other.     We are told by the privileged few that we must wait to gain the same privileges. Time is up. A Derry woman has launched a new four-week ‚ÄòKick-Start‚Äô nutritional programme designed to help tackle stress, anxiety, depression and physical health conditions through a holistic approach. Jade Bradley, who is originally from Hatmore Park in the Foyle Springs area of the city, is the founder of Restore Nutrition, a wellness company that specialises in helping people with their nutrition to deliver a better quality of le. Jade embarked on her own mental and physical health journey several years ago having struggled with anxiety. She used a blended approach which included yoga, meditation, music, therapy and the input from a kinesiologist that advised on food issues and intolerances. googletag.cmd.push Within two months of implementing these changes, Jade saw a massive change resulting in better sleep, more energy and a feeling of being more ‚Äòrestored.‚Äô It was this that sparked her desire to educate herself in naturopathic nutrition. She moved to London and studied at the College of Naturopathic Medicine and became a member of the Complementary and Natural Healthcare Council. She launched Restore Nutrition in  and the company has since gone from strength to strength. working with over  private clients and organisations including, Seagate, Business in the Community, Hurt, Waterside Neighbourhood Partnership, Belfast Food Network, Hillcrest, Culmore Hub, Foyle Women‚Äôs Information Group, Derry Well Woman and Youth Action. googletag.cmd.push Speaking about her new programme, Jade said: ‚ÄúWe are living in a stressed out society, and having the main pillars of health and wellbeing in place is essential to help deal with stress and anxiety. If the fundamentals aren‚Äôt in place, it is impossible for us to excel.‚Äù Jade said these fundamentals were more important than ever given the challenging times we are all in. She added: ‚ÄúI centre our work around four pillars which we delve into on the ‚ÄòKick Start‚Äô programme namely: hydration, reducing toxic load, restoring with whole foods and managing stress and sleep.‚Äù She said she has found most people want a quick fix or a magic pill when it came to their health and wellbeing journey.     ‚ÄúUnfortunately, this does not exist,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt is best to make small changes incrementally and embark on this journey in stages starting off with the fundamentals which is exactly what we do in our new programme. ‚ÄúFurthermore, it is so important to tackle mental health issues with an all-round approach and this is why I have worked with local mental health therapist, Caroline McMenamin, on many projects over the past two years and plan to do more collaborations throughout the year.‚Äù The ‚ÄòKick Start‚Äô nutrition programme is available for business groups, charities, community groups and inidual attendees and runs over four weeks in one-hour sessions. Derry and Longford have named their teams for Saturday evenings league opener in Pearse Park . Nine of the Derry team started the  meeting of the teams, a night when Benny Heron, Paul Cassidy and Conor Glass came off the bench. Having handed out  debuts in his first season as Derry boss, there is a more settled look to Rory Gallaghers squad this season. Paul Cassidy is listed to start for the second time after making his full debut against Offaly in Tullamore last season. There is a first inclusion for Gareth McKinless since Derrys  All-Ireland Qualier win over Cavan. googletag.cmd.push Ciaran McFaul played virtually every minute under Gallagher last season, bar a th minute late black card in the McKenna Cup against Monaghan and being replaced in the th minute of their win over Louth. He is one of four Glen men listed to start on Saturday. Danny Tallon, who started all  games last season, isnt included in the starting line-up. There is no place for Slaughtneil defender Karl McKaigue who has made a full recovery from the torn Achilles sustained on club hurling championship duty last summer. The only three members of the current  yet to make their debuts are Bellaghy duo Ronan McFaul and Conleth McShane, as well as Glen goalkeeper Connlan Bradley. googletag.cmd.push Goals from Patrick Kearney and Paul Cassidy helped Derry to victory when the sides met last season at Celtic Park. Derry and Longford have met eight times in the last two decades, in league and championship. The Oakleafers have to go back to  for their last win at Pearse Park, when two Anthony Tohill goals and an inspired performance from current selector Enda Muldoon put Derry on their way to victory. In the other game in Division  North, Ulster champions take on Fermanagh on Saturday evening in Brewster Park . Derry will face Fermanagh next Saturday in Owenbeg . Derry and Longford have named their teams for Saturday evenings league opener in Pearse Park . Nine of the Derry team started the  meeting of the teams, a night when Benny Heron, Paul Cassidy and Conor Glass came off the bench. Having handed out  debuts in his first season as Derry boss, there is a more settled look to Rory Gallaghers squad this season. Paul Cassidy is listed to start for the second time after making his full debut against Offaly in Tullamore last season. There is a first inclusion for Gareth McKinless since Derrys  All-Ireland Qualier win over Cavan. googletag.cmd.push Ciaran McFaul played virtually every minute under Gallagher last season, bar a th minute late black card in the McKenna Cup against Monaghan and being replaced in the th minute of their win over Louth. He is one of four Glen men listed to start on Saturday. Danny Tallon, who started all  games last season, isnt included in the starting line-up. There is no place for Slaughtneil defender Karl McKaigue who has made a full recovery from the torn Achilles sustained on club hurling championship duty last summer. The only three members of the current  yet to make their debuts are Bellaghy duo Ronan McFaul and Conleth McShane, as well as Glen goalkeeper Connlan Bradley. googletag.cmd.push Goals from Patrick Kearney and Paul Cassidy helped Derry to victory when the sides met last season at Celtic Park. Derry and Longford have met eight times in the last two decades, in league and championship. The Oakleafers have to go back to  for their last win at Pearse Park, when two Anthony Tohill goals and an inspired performance from current selector Enda Muldoon put Derry on their way to victory. In the other game in Division  North, Ulster champions take on Fermanagh on Saturday evening in Brewster Park . Derry will face Fermanagh next Saturday in Owenbeg . Derry manager Rory Gallagher was very pleased to get the  season off to a winning start. By hook or by crook wed have liked to have got out of there with a victory, Gallagher commented after Derrys - to - win over Longford on Saturday night. We performed fairly well...very well at times in the second half. It was a lot more comfortable than wed ever have expected, he added. An upbeat Derry boss said the victory was a great reward for the efforts of the squad in the off-season. After getting the full squad back on board after last seasons Derry county finals, he felt the build-up to the Armagh championship game pleased him, after which the squad were left in no doubt of the effort required before Christmas, ahead of their  promotion push. googletag.cmd.push They have done the work with Peterand with Anne Marieand I am delighted with the condition they are in, Gallagher pointed out. Derry were six points clear at half time of Saturdays clash in a rainswept Pearse Park, but Gallagher admitted it shouldve been more. I was bitterly disappointed we only had eight points at half-time, we shouldve been sitting with - or - at our ease and that was Niallkicking a couple of fties in tough conditions. I felt we left scores too easily behind and to be honest,Longford had been more clinical or when you move up the gears against opposition higher up the isions wed have suffered for it. googletag.cmd.push Fermanagh were narrow winners over Ulster champions Cavan on Saturday night and come to Owenbeg next week for a top of the table clash. One of the most prominent locations in Derrys city centre is set for a new lease of le. The buildings at  and  Strand Road have been empty since a Boojum restaurant closed last March. Now, as business le in the city slowly restarts after the devastating impact of the pandemic, it has emerged that a new coffee house is to open in the Strand Road buildings which lie at the busy junction with Clarendon Street. Final preparations are being made for the opening of the Industry Deli  Coffee House. The owners of the business say it will be opening soon. googletag.cmd.push This will be seen as a huge boost for business le in the Strand Road area. Before Boojum, the Sandwich Company occupied the Strand Road building for many years. As business le in the city centre slowly s, Brian Tierney, Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, has been visiting local shops to offer the councils support. He urged people to shop local as much as possible. I was glad to meet with some of the local businesses across our district this week and hear more about the positive steps forward now that many of those businesses have reopened or are preparing for a scheduled reopening in the coming weeks. googletag.cmd.push It was fantastic to see lots of people supporting those businesses while I was out and about and to see that all of the businesses have measures in place to instill confidence in all members of the public that they can support local and be assured that everything is in place to protect both themselves and staff. I can fully appreciate how much of a challenge the past year has been for our businesses across a wide range of sectors, and I look forward to the weeks ahead when we hope to see more of those sectors reopening and ing to a more normal operation of business,‚Äù said the Mayor. Two County Derry teenagers have made a heartfelt plea for people to talk about suicide in men to mark the th anniversary of their fathers death. Eaacutebha Mullanand Ciaroacuten Mullan , from Ballerin, have written about the loss of their father Kieran Squealer Mullan in , when the siblings were just five and three years old. Ahead of a k sponsored run this weekend in aid of the Mental Health Awareness charity, Eaacutebha and Ciaroacutens mother, Collette, has shared her childrens plea to break the taboo around mens mental health. ‚ÄúOn May  , it will be  years since Ciaroacuten and I last saw our Daddy. With cold shock, I realise that means hes been gone for  years longer than I knew him,‚Äù wrote Eaacutebha. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúWe were only five and three when he took his own le. For many people, a period of time relieves much of the pain, and makes it easier to move on. ‚ÄúBut for us, in many ways, its got worse. Losing a parent at five and three meant we didnt really understand death. I didnt even know it was suicide until I was in P. ‚ÄúOur Daddys death has left us with years of unsolved questions, new and fresh situations to face without a father. ‚ÄúEven from the day he died, we are still finding out new things about him to add to the tiny memories we thankfully have. Five years is no time to know someone well. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúI wish we could go back to those days when we were just a little boy and girl, too young to notice how down our Daddy really was. Eaacutebha has posted details of the sponsored runs route on social media. ‚ÄúI wish we could spread them throughout the rest of our lives knowing what people are thinking and going through, hoping we could help them in any possible way. ‚ÄúWhy cant we swap the day he held us as a baby at our Christening, so he could watch us play Gaelic, win big matches and watch us succeed in le  ‚ÄúTen years on and we are still listening to his favourite songs, watching the one existing video of him to remember his voice, crying on Fathers Day or his birthday, or any random day.     ‚ÄúWe still cant let our Daddy go. Everyone thinks we might have moved on, because it happened such a long time ago. ‚ÄúBut they dont know how it feels to look at the same few photographs, knowing there will never be any more. ‚ÄúThey dont know how strange it feels to think we once had two parents. They dont know what its like to sit and talk to your Daddy at a gravestone at  and  knowing that he didnt want to be here. ‚ÄúIf we let him go, hes gone forever, and we cant take that. The effect of suicide isnt just the loss of the person who left you behind, its the shadow always at your heel.‚Äù Eaacutebha and Ciaroacuten have shared their story in the hope it will help others to speak out about their mental health. ‚ÄúTen years on, and suicide is still the leading cause of death for men under ,‚Äù said Eaacutebha. ‚ÄúEvery day, men who feel like our Daddy did bottle up their feelings, try to appear strong, and drive themselves further into darkness. ‚ÄúEvery day,  of them take their lives, leaving people like Ciaroacuten and I lost and heartbroken. And every day, we wish we could change what happened. ‚ÄúFor our Daddy, the sun will never come out again, but the more we talk about it, the more we listen, the more others will live to see another day and the more the shadows will fade.‚Äù] The k sponsored run in memory of Kieran Squealer Mullan will take place on Sunday May , with all proceeds going to the Mental Health Awareness charity. A review of the boundary of Derry City and Strabane District Council is underway. Government Boundaries Commissioner Sarah Havlin has outlined further details about her review of the  district council boundaries and the proposed timetable and process for public consultation. This includes publishing a short information video to outline the review process and highlighting why and how people can get involved. This also coincides with the start of a series of ‚ÄòMeet the Commissioner‚Äô briefing events with council representatives from across all  councils. By the end of July this year, the Commissioner plans to publish provisional proposals, outlining any proposed changes to local government boundaries. googletag.cmd.push The closing date for written submissions about these provisional proposals will be September  this year. After this, a series of public hearings will be held to gather further feedback and these will be subject to the relevant covid- public health guidance at that time. Thereafter, there will be a period of analysis of the representations and public hearing reports, before the preparation of revised proposals which will again be subject to further consultation. The review is something that by law has to happen every eight- years and although the last review took place in   with the final recommendations from that providing the basis for the last review of local government boundaries which after legislation and elections etc, took effect from  when the new councils came into being. googletag.cmd.push The last review, which saw Derry City Council and Strabane District Council combine to make Derry City and Strabane District Council, coincided with the change in local government which saw the signicant change from  to  councils so was more substantial in nature. This review will take into account changes in electoral changes housing changes among other things since  and make recommendation on the boundaries of the  current districts and the ious wards that make them up. It‚Äôs hard to know what the initial proposals will show as modelling electoral analysis etc is ongoing but there may well be some local government boundaries changing.     The review will also examine the potential for changes to the names of local wards to reflect local considerations. The review, when completed next year, will then need to be legislated on before any actual boundary changes would take effect. Boundary Commissioner, Sarah Havlin, is encouraging everyone with an interest to get involved in what she described this important review. everyone with an interest to get involved. ‚ÄúWe have also published an information video to highlight how and why people should get involved. The outcomes will inform the make-up of local government in the foreseeable future andwill consider the impact of electorate changes since  and other recent developments. ‚ÄúThe process is about independently ensuring electoral equality and fairness across Northern Ireland, with the aim that all the wards within a district should, as far as possible, have a similar number of electors. ‚ÄúWith that I mind, it‚Äôs important that we hear the views of local people and their representatives on these matters, and I would encourage people to regularly check our website and social media channels for more information on how they can have their voice heard in this process.‚Äù Review details can be found athttps:www. lgbc-ni.org.uk or via Twitter and Facebook @LGBCNI.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. The funeral has taken place of primary school teacher Catherine McCann from Lavey, who tragically passed away this week. Mourners at the service in Our Lady of Mercy Church in Lavey heard how Catherine showered the children she taught with love and was devoted to her family. Officiating at the funeral, parish priest Fr Eamon Graham said she was a beautul person. ‚ÄúIf I was to mention this morning all the people who Catherine loved and who she in turn was loved by, we would be here all day,‚Äù he told the congregation. ‚ÄúThe past few days I was trying to think how I would sum up Catherine she was beautul inside and outside, in every aspect of le. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúShe loved all the good things in le. She always had her hair done and presented herself better than any of the rest of us. ‚ÄúBehind that, it wasnt a facade. It was a reflection of the goodness within her. She lived her le in a wonderful way.‚Äù Fr Graham told those gathered in the church how Catherine had doted over her many nieces and nephews, and encouraged them to keep her memory alive by following her example. Her love of both those in her family and the children she taught was central to her le, a le in which her faith was strong. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúYou know every child she ever taught, because she brought all the childrens bothers and woes home. She loved the children she taught, particularly in Creggan,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúShe had a special love of her godchildren because her faith was important. She loved God deeply and many people are closer to God today because they encountered Catherine.‚Äù A proud Lavey woman, she was deeply involved in the local community. She attended the local primary school and was steeped in the areas GAA tradition. ‚ÄúIn our own parish, Catherine was so involved in the GAA, the camogie. She was a pupil at our school and the teachers remembered her as a pupil and a student teacher,‚Äù said Fr Graham.     ‚ÄúWhen she was dealing with student teachers, she always went the extra mile. Teaching wasnt just a job for her, it was a vocation. ‚ÄúShe was a perfectionist in every way possible, but she missed her mummy. It is our hope, prayer and belief that she is with her mother and with God.‚Äù Erins Own GAC led their own tribute to Catherine online. ‚ÄúLavey GAC is greatly shocked and saddened to learn of the untimely death of our former senior camogie player, Catherine McCann,‚Äù they said. ‚ÄúToday and forever well remember Catherine McCann. Every team with Catherine on it was a better team.‚Äù Catherine taught for  years in Creggan Primary School, near Randalstown, County Antrim, and the school paid tribute to her kindness. ‚ÄúMiss Mc Cann taught in our school for  years. Tributes have been paid to a former teacher at a Derry school. John Flood, a former teacher and vice-principal at Rosemount Primary School, passed away on Wednesday. Mr Flood worked at the local school from  to . Current principal of Rosemount Primary School, Paul Bradley, said it was with great sadness that everyone associated with the school had learned of Mr Floods death. John was a very popular member of the Rosemount teaching staffand indeed his association with the school has continued long after his retirement with grandchildren now attending. As principal, I had the great pleasure of meeting John during his many visits to the school, as he arrived early to pick up the grandchildren and visit the office for a bit of banter with staff. googletag.cmd.push His wit, good humour and good nature shone out during those years and it was easy to see how pupils would have enjoyed his relaxed manner while always being aware of the high standards he expected and worked hard to achieve, from all those who were privileged enough to be in his class. John was very proud of his association with our school. As a school community, we express our heartfelt sadness to his we Anne, his sons Mark and John, his daughters Shona and Ciara, his grandchildren, great grandchild and extended family circle. Mr Flood will be buried today following a service at .am at St Eugenes Cathedral. googletag.cmd.push  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Tributes have been paid to a former teacher at a Derry school. John Flood, a former teacher and vice-principal at Rosemount Primary School, passed away on Wednesday. Mr Flood worked at the local school from  to . Current principal of Rosemount Primary School, Paul Bradley, said it was with great sadness that everyone associated with the school had learned of Mr Floods death. John was a very popular member of the Rosemount teaching staffand indeed his association with the school has continued long after his retirement with grandchildren now attending. As principal, I had the great pleasure of meeting John during his many visits to the school, as he arrived early to pick up the grandchildren and visit the office for a bit of banter with staff. googletag.cmd.push His wit, good humour and good nature shone out during those years and it was easy to see how pupils would have enjoyed his relaxed manner while always being aware of the high standards he expected and worked hard to achieve, from all those who were privileged enough to be in his class. John was very proud of his association with our school. As a school community, we express our heartfelt sadness to his we Anne, his sons Mark and John, his daughters Shona and Ciara, his grandchildren, great grandchild and extended family circle. Mr Flood will be buried today following a service at .am at St Eugenes Cathedral. googletag.cmd.push  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Two oclock and half three. Before inter-county football shoehorned the club game into whatever orice it can find, the senior and reserve double header on a Sunday was set in stone across Derry. With cars filtering in the lane from after three oclock, stalwarts would perch themselves along the fence to run their eye over the reserve action. The senior managers ears would often be burning, as some doting Daddies would question their sons non-selection for the seniors. ‚ÄúThat man hasnt a clue,‚Äù youd sometimes hear. A stellar showing in the reserve game would have you hauled ashore early, to stay fresh for a cameo senior appearance. Some saw it as elevation. The player himself would be frustrated at having his vintage display cut short. googletag.cmd.push Thats the problem with almost being on the senior team. Youre caught between two stools. Everyone  knows where they stand in the pecking order. Johnny must be in the seniors plans,‚Äù the auld hands would mumble as he trotted off. He might get five minutes in the senior game. He might get . He might get none. It just depended on how things were going. Thats how it was. If another player on the reserve team, lets call him Paddy, kicked the last two scores, made a goal line block or emptied some man out over the sideline, hed dine off legendary status. googletag.cmd.push ‚ÄúYoud some game Paddy,‚Äù somebody would tell him, over the wire, as he pulled on a senior sub jersey. ‚ÄúYoud be starting in the seniors every weekI was over that team.‚Äù By the time Paddy pulls up a stool at the bar later that night, and puts manners in his first pint, his bone crunching shoulder challenge has now exaggerated ten times over. ‚ÄúHe put yer man through the wire,‚Äù would be the latest. And nobody is going to dampen a good story. That was Sunday every week in the club leagues. Tuesday night at training was the time to put in your shout for the senior team next week. And so the cycle continued.     The alternative is playing the reserve game afterwards, with anyone not getting a decentof time in the senior game will get their fill of football. But the self esteem must take an awful battering as almost everyone leaves after the senior game. It depends what your take is. As much as that model served the GAA well, it has its downfall. With the level of preparation at club level going through the roof, the whole weeks diet, rest and social le revolves around the Sunday. Social media went into meltdown last week, with everyone salivating over their Friday night slot for senior games, like Downs tried and tested formula. In theory, it is a great idea. Friday night pints. Saturday and Sunday to take your better half or family out for the day Training on a Monday and Wednesday night, ready to go again. There are two drawbacks. At the height of the Celtic Tiger, with players working in Dublin or further afield, it was a squeeze to get home for a training session at eight oclock, never mind racing home for six oclock to play a reserve game as part of a double header. Secondly, splitting the reserve and senior games to dferent days leaves twice the amount of travel, for the fringe senior players who will be on both squads, while leaving you back where you started with a reserve game on the Sunday. For me, Saturday six oclock and half seven is the answer. It is somewhere in between. It leaves Saturday night free for players to do as they please and get themselves in order for training the following week. The only people it will affect are those who are mixing their GAA with the local soccer or rugby team. But, maybe this is where a compromise needs to be reached. In some places, soccer and rugby keep players fitness ticking over during the off-season. And vice versa. Rather than going loggerheads, clubs could select a certain number of their games for Sunday until the soccer and rugby seasons are over, before moving to Saturday. It wouldnt be every club. In a way, it also gives local GAA clubs an advantage. How many times have you wanted to go and watch the crunch game of the weekend, but cant because you have a game of your own. I always use the example of going to watch Lavey and Ballinderry in a late Sunday evening game. The rest of Derry had the chance to call in on their way home. There was a bumper crowd and an electric atmosphere for players. Everybody is a winner. So of the  games in the Derry A and B leagues, have half on a Sunday, half on a Saturday and one on a Friday night. Set the dates in stone, which gives players six free Sundays they wouldnt normally have had. There is the option of taking your kids to the pool, book a weekend away, nurse a hangover or watch a county game. The licence to do any of those things will make GAA less of a strain on the weekend. The Sunday fixture does suit the supporter, but they arent obliged to go to a game every weekend andthey do, itll take up three hours at the most. Players are dferent. Theyll dedicate Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday, with all the sacrices they make in between. Their voice should be heard above the rest. Imagine the weekend Paddy would have, living off kicking three points to win the reserve game and pummelling the oppositions hatchet man in the process.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories.
